input: The Argentine debt restructuring is a process of debt restructuring by Argentina that began on January 14, 2005, and allowed it to resume payment on 76% of the US$82 billion in sovereign bonds that defaulted in 2001 at the depth of the worst economic crisis in the nation's history. A second debt restructuring in 2010 brought the percentage of bonds under some form of repayment to 93%, though ongoing disputes with holdouts remained. Bondholders who participated in the restructuring settled for repayments of around 30% of face value and deferred payment terms, and began to be paid punctually; the value of their nearly worthless bonds also began to rise. The remaining 7% of bondholders were later repaid 25% less then they were demanding, after centre-right and US-aligned leader
syn: The debt restructuring in Argentina, initiated on January 14, 2005, enabled the country to continue payments on 76% of the US$82 billion in defaulted sovereign bonds from the critical economic downturn in 2001. A subsequent restructuring in 2010 increased this to 93%, despite continuous disagreements with some creditors. Investors accepting the restructuring received around 30% of the original value in repayments and extended payment schedules, and their previously devalued bonds started to appreciate. The last 7% of investors later received 25% less than their asking price, after negotiations with a center-right, pro-US administration.

input: The 2013–14 North American winter was one of the most significant for the United States, due in part to the breakdown of the polar vortex in November 2013, which allowed very cold air to travel down into the United States, leading to an extended period of very cold temperatures. The pattern continued mostly uninterrupted throughout the winter and numerous significant winter storms affected the Eastern United States, with the most notable one being a powerful winter storm that dumped ice and snow in the Southeastern United States and the Northeastern United States in mid-February. Most of the cold weather abated by the end of March, though a few winter storms did affect the Western United States towards the end of the winter. While there is no well-agreed-upon date
syn: The 2013–14 North American winter season was one of the most notable for the United States, thanks to the disruption of the polar vortex in November 2013, which allowed extremely cold air to move down into the United States, leading to a prolonged period of intense cold temperatures. The pattern continued largely uninterrupted throughout the winter and several major winter storms impacted the Eastern United States, with the most significant being a powerful winter storm that dropped ice and snow in the Southeastern United States and the Northeastern United States in mid-February. Most of the cold conditions subsided by the end of March, though a few winter storms did affect the Western United States towards the season's conclusion. While there is no universally accepted date.

input: Wrestle Kingdom 8 in Tokyo Dome was a professional wrestling pay-per-view (PPV) event produced by the New Japan Pro-Wrestling (NJPW) promotion, which took place at the Tokyo Dome in Tokyo, Japan on January 4, 2014. It was the 23rd January 4 Tokyo Dome Show and the eighth held under the "Wrestle Kingdom" name. Like the previous year, the event aired worldwide on internet pay-per-view (iPPV). Wrestle Kingdom is traditionally NJPW's biggest event of the year and has been described as their equivalent to WWE's WrestleMania.The event featured ten matches, six of which were contested for championships. For the first time in twenty years, the National Wrestling Alliance (NWA) World Heavyweight Championship was defended during the event with NWA representative Rob Conway defending against Satoshi Kojima. The event was
syn: Wrestle Kingdom 8 at Tokyo Dome was an event organized by New Japan Pro-Wrestling (NJPW), occurring in Tokyo's Tokyo Dome on January 4, 2014. It marked the 23rd edition of the January 4 Tokyo Dome Show and the eighth installment of the "Wrestle Kingdom" series. Similar to the prior year, this event was broadcast globally on internet pay-per-view (iPPV). Wrestle Kingdom is typically seen as NJPW's premier annual event, akin to WWE's WrestleMania. The event showcased ten bouts, with six featuring title defenses. Uniquely, after two decades, the National Wrestling Alliance (NWA) World Heavyweight Championship was defended at this spectacle, with NWA's Rob Conway taking on Satoshi Kojima. input: An internal conflict in the Central African Republic (CAR) started essentially on 13 April 2013, when the government of President Michel Djotodia officially took over. The fighting was between the government of the Central African Republic's former Séléka coalition of rebel groups, who are mainly from the Muslim minority, and the mainly Christian anti-balaka coalition. The conflict was part of the ongoing Central African Republic Civil War (2012–present). International organisations, such as the United Nations, had warned of a possible genocide. UNSC resolution 2122 authorised the African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (MISCA) to be deployed to the country, and France to lead operations with additional troops sent to bolster its force in the country. Following a summit of Economic Community of Central African States
syn: The internal strife in the Central African Republic (CAR) officially commenced on 13 April 2013, when President Michel Djotodia's administration assumed control. This conflict involved the government of the Central African Republic's preceding Séléka rebel alliances, primarily comprising the Muslim minority, against the predominantly Christian anti-balaka factions. This violence was a segment of the broader Central African Republic Civil War (2012–current). International entities, like the United Nations, cautioned against a potential genocide. UNSC resolution 2122 sanctioned the deployment of the African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (MISCA), and authorized France to spearhead operations with extra soldiers dispatched to strengthen its presence in the nation, following a conference of the Economic Community of Central African States.

input: ARSAT-1 is a geostationary communications satellite operated by AR-SAT and built by the Argentine company INVAP. ARSAT-1 was launched into orbit on October 16, 2014, from French Guiana alongside Intelsat-30 satellite using an Ariane 5 rocket. It is expected to be located at 72° West longitude geostationary slot. ARSAT-1 is the first geostationary satellite built in Latin America. Total cost of the satellite is 270 million US dollars.ARSAT-1 carries a total of 24 IEEE Ku band (NATO J-band) transponders. Twelve will be operating at 36 MHz, eight at 54 MHz and four at 72 MHz, for a total bandwidth of 1152 MHz. It will offer a wide range of telecommunications, data transmission, telephone and television services mainly across all of Argentina, Chile, Uruguay and Paraguay including direct broadcast
syn: ARSAT-1 is a geostationary communications satellite managed by AR-SAT and constructed by the Argentine firm INVAP. ARSAT-1 was sent into space on October 16, 2014, from French Guiana together with the Intelsat-30 satellite using an Ariane 5 launcher. It is slated to be positioned at a 72° West longitude geostationary slot. ARSAT-1 represents the first geostationary satellite fabricated in Latin America. The total investment for the satellite is 270 million USD. ARSAT-1 is equipped with a total of 24 IEEE Ku band (NATO J-band) transponders. Twelve are to function at 36 MHz, eight at 54 MHz, and four at 72 MHz, equating to a total bandwidth of 1152 MHz. It is designed to provide a broad scope of telecommunications, data transmission, telephony, and television services mainly throughout Argentina, Chile, Uruguay, and Paraguay including direct to home broadcasts.

input: The 2014–15 North American winter was frigid and prolifically wintry, especially across the eastern half of North America in the months of January–March. The season began early, with many places in North America experiencing their first wintry weather during mid-November. A period of below-average temperatures affected much of the contiguous United States, and several records were broken. An early trace of snowfall was recorded in Arkansas. There were greater accumulations of snow across parts of Oklahoma as well. A quasi-permanent phenomenon referred to as the polar vortex may have been partly responsible for the cold weather. Temperatures in much of the United States dropped 15 to 35 °F (8.3 to 19 °C) below average by November 19, following a southward "dip" of the polar vortex into the eastern
syn: The 2014–15 North American winter season was extremely cold and abounded in snowy conditions, particularly in the eastern regions of North America during January–March. This cold season kicked off prematurely, with numerous areas across North America feeling their initial winter conditions by mid-November. An episode of temperatures lower than the average impacted a vast part of the contiguous United States, breaking several temperature records. An early instance of snow was observed in Arkansas, with heavier snowfall occurring in various areas of Oklahoma too. The sustained cold spell, known as the polar vortex, might have contributed to the chilly conditions. By November 19, temperatures across a large portion of the United States had plummeted 15 to 35 °F (8.3 to 19 °C) beneath the norm, attributed to the polar vortex's southern "plunge" into the eastern United States.

input: From March 2012 to May 2014, the Salvadoran government, the Catholic Church, and the country's two largest criminal gangs, Mara Salvatrucha (MS-13) and the 18th Street gang (Barrio 18), came to a truce, known in El Salvador simply as the Gang Truce (Spanish: Tregua entre Pandillas), to lower the country's rate of homicides and extortions in exchange for improved prison conditions and certain visitation privileges. The truce's principal negotiators were Minister of Public Security David Munguía Payés, former deputy Raúl Mijango, and Bishop Fabio Colindres, and the negotiations were overseen by President Mauricio Funes. The existence of the truce was alleged by the online newspaper El Faro in early March 2012, after 30 gang leaders were transferred from a maximum-security prison to a lower-security prison, and confirmed after
syn: Between March 2012 and May 2014, the government of El Salvador, the Catholic Church, and the two primary criminal organizations, Mara Salvatrucha (MS-13) and 18th Street gang (Barrio 18), engaged in a ceasefire known in the nation as the Gang Truce (Spanish: Tregua entre Pandillas). This agreement aimed to decrease the nationwide levels of murders and robberies in return for better conditions in jails and certain rights to visits. Key figures in brokering this accord were Security Minister David Munguía Payés, ex-legislator Raúl Mijango, and Monsignor Fabio Colindres, under the supervision of President Mauricio Funes. The online news outlet El Faro first suggested the truce's existence in early March 2012, following the relocation of 30 leaders of these gangs from high-security confinement to facilities with less stringent security measures, with confirmation coming afterward.

input: General elections were held in Bosnia and Herzegovina on 12 October 2014. They decided the makeup of Bosnia and Herzegovina's Presidency as well as national, entity, and cantonal governments. Voter turnout was 54.4%.The elections for the House of Representatives were divided into two; one for the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina and one for Republika Srpska. In the presidential election, voters in the Federation re-elected Bosniak Bakir Izetbegović and elected Croat Dragan Čović, while voters in Republika Srpska elected Serb Mladen Ivanić. The Party of Democratic Action emerged as the largest party in the House of Representatives, winning 10 of the 42 seats. While the Bosniak member Bakir Izetbegović was the only member of the tripartite Presidency to be re-elected, Serb member Mladen Ivanić was chosen as the
syn: General elections were conducted in Bosnia and Herzegovina on 12 October 2014. These elections determined the composition of Bosnia and Herzegovina's Presidency along with national, entity, and cantonal administrations. Voter participation was 54.4%. The elections for the House of Representatives were split into two parts; one for the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina and another for Republika Srpska. In the presidential race, voters in the Federation re-elected Bosniak Bakir Izetbegović and elected Croat Dragan Čović, whereas voters in Republika Srpska elected Serb Mladen Ivanić. The Party of Democratic Action became the most significant party in the House of Representatives, securing 10 of the 42 seats. While the Bosniak member Bakir Izetbegović was the only member of the three-person Presidency to secure re-election, Serb member Mladen Ivanić was elected as the.

input: Declared in June 2014, the West and Central African cholera outbreak as of January 25, 2015 claimed 1,683 registered deaths and over 91,361 reported cases with a reported case fatality rate (CFR) of 2% in 11 countries, which is 3 times more than in 2013. The case fatality ratio is high in the Sahelian area, equal or greater than 2%, especially in Nigeria, Chad, Cameroon and Niger. Nigeria, Ghana and Democratic Republic of the Congo being the most affected countries with Ghana reporting its worst outbreak since 1982.In January 2015 the Greater Accra Region and Volta region still reported cases of Cholera while in the rest of Ghana the outbreak was declared over. As of January 11 the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Ghana and Nigeria are the
syn: Initiated in June 2014, the cholera epidemic in West and Central Africa, by January 25, 2015, had resulted in 1,683 recorded fatalities and more than 91,361 identified cases, with a case fatality ratio (CFR) of 2% across 11 nations. This figure is triple that of 2013. The case fatality rate is particularly elevated in the Sahelian zone, hitting 2% or higher, notably in Nigeria, Chad, Cameroon, and Niger. Nigeria, Ghana, and the Democratic Republic of the Congo were the hardest hit, with Ghana experiencing its most severe epidemic since 1982. By January 2015, both the Greater Accra and Volta regions were still acknowledging cholera cases, whereas the remainder of Ghana had announced the conclusion of the outbreak. Up to January 11, the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Ghana, and Nigeria were particularly affected.

input: The Report of the Commission of Inquiry on Human Rights in the Democratic People's Republic of Korea is the landmark document resulting from the investigations on human rights in North Korea commissioned by the United Nations Human Rights Council in 2013 and concluded in 2014.The report unequivocally concluded that the North Korean government systematically violated human rights including freedom of thought, expression and religion; freedom from discrimination; freedom of movement and residence; and the right to food.The Commission further determined that North Korea had committed crimes against humanity and manifestly failed to uphold its responsibility to protect. These crimes entail "extermination, murder, enslavement, torture, imprisonment, rape, forced abortions and other sexual violence, persecution on political, religious, racial and gender grounds, the forcible transfer of populations, the enforced disappearance
syn: The Report of the Commission of Inquiry on Human Rights in the Democratic People's Republic of Korea is the landmark document resulting from the inquiries into human rights in North Korea initiated by the United Nations Human Rights Council in 2013 and finalized in 2014. The report decisively concluded that the North Korean regime systematically infringed upon human rights including the right to freedom of thought, expression, and religion; freedom from discrimination; the right to move and reside freely; and the right to food. The Commission additionally determined that North Korea had perpetrated crimes against humanity and glaringly failed to fulfill its duty to protect. These crimes include "extermination, murder, enslavement, torture, imprisonment, rape, forced abortions and other forms of sexual violence, persecution on political, religious, racial, and gender grounds, the forced relocation of populations, the enforced disappearance."

input: Azerbaijan participated in the Eurovision Song Contest 2014 with the song "Start a Fire" written by Stefan Örn, Johan Kronlund and Alessandra Günthardt. The song was performed by Dilara Kazimova. The Azerbaijani Eurovision entrant for the 2014 contest in Copenhagen, Denmark was selected through Böyük Səhnə, a talent show organised by the Azerbaijani broadcaster İctimai Television (İTV). Following three elimination shows and a final on 2 March 2014, a five-member jury selected Dilara Kazimova as the winner. The song "Start a Fire" was internally selected and presented to the public on 16 March. Azerbaijan was drawn to compete in the first semi-final of the Eurovision Song Contest which took place on 6 May 2014. Performing during the show in position 8, "Start a Fire" was announced among the
syn: Azerbaijan was represented in the Eurovision Song Contest 2014 by the track "Start a Fire," crafted by Stefan Örn, Johan Kronlund, and Alessandra Günthardt. This tune was delivered by Dilara Kazimova. The selection of Azerbaijan's representative for the contest in Copenhagen, Denmark, was made through Böyük Səhnə, a competition show set up by Azerbaijani broadcaster İctimai Television (İTV). After three preliminary rounds and a conclusive event on March 2, 2014, a panel of five judges chose Dilara Kazimova as the victor. The track "Start a Fire" was chosen by the organization and revealed to the audience on March 16. Azerbaijan was allocated to participate in the first semi-final of the Eurovision Song Contest, which occurred on May 6, 2014. Performing in the show at slot 8, "Start a Fire" was confirmed as one of the advancements.

input: Lars Joachim Mittank (born February 9, 1986) is a German man who disappeared on July 8, 2014, near Varna Airport in Varna, Bulgaria. Mittank was vacationing at the Golden Sands resort, where he was supposedly involved in a fight, and was subsequently unable to fly home with his friends for health reasons. Mittank was documented acting strangely while alone in Bulgaria. He called home to his mother claiming that people were trying to kill him. On the day when he was supposed to fly home, Mittank went to the Varna Airport to consult with a doctor. He was later seen on airport security footage running out of the airport and towards an adjacent forest. He has never been seen since. The case has generated intense interest, and the
syn: Lars Joachim Mittank (born February 9, 1986) is a German individual who vanished on July 8, 2014, close to Varna Airport in Varna, Bulgaria. Mittank was on holiday at the Golden Sands resort, where he was reportedly involved in an altercation, and consequently was unable to return home with his companions due to medical reasons. Mittank exhibited unusual behavior while on his own in Bulgaria. He contacted his mother, claiming that individuals were plotting against his life. On the day he was scheduled to return, Mittank went to the Varna Airport to see a medical professional. He was later captured by security cameras sprinting from the airport into a nearby woodland. He has not been observed since. The case has sparked widespread fascination.

input: In 2014, a series of groundbreaking diplomatic meetings was held between Wang Yu-chi, in his official capacity as the Minister of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) of the Republic of China (ROC), and Zhang Zhijun, the Minister of the Taiwan Affairs Office (TAO) of the People's Republic of China (PRC). The first meeting took place in Nanjing on 11 February 2014 when Wang visited mainland China, the very first official contact between the two governments across the Taiwan Strait after the end of Chinese Civil War in 1949. The tour of Wang and his delegates lasted from 11 to 14 February in Nanjing and Shanghai.On 25–28 June 2014, Zhang paid a retrospective visit to Taiwan in order to rebuild ties in the aftermath of the Sunflower Movement. It
syn: In 2014, a series of groundbreaking diplomatic discussions occurred between Wang Yu-chi, in his capacity as the Minister of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) of the Republic of China (ROC), and Zhang Zhijun, the head of the Taiwan Affairs Office (TAO) of the People's Republic of China (PRC). The initial meeting occurred in Nanjing on 11 February 2014 when Wang made a historic visit to mainland China, marking the first official interaction between the two administrations across the Taiwan Strait since the cessation of the Chinese Civil War in 1949. Wang's delegation and he were in Nanjing and Shanghai from 11 to 14 February. On 25–28 June 2014, Zhang reciprocated with a visit to Taiwan aimed at mending relations following the Sunflower Movement, making this exchange a significant effort to rebuild connections.

input: The 40th G7 summit was held 4–5 June, 2014 in Brussels, Belgium. It was originally scheduled to be held as the “40th G8 summit” and be hosted by Russia in the Black Sea resort of Sochi. However, the other seven countries decided on 24 March that the summit would be instead held without Russia in Brussels.Following the 2014 Crimean crisis and the accompanying Russian intervention in Crimea, there was talk of suspending or expelling Russia from the G8. On 24 March, British Prime Minister David Cameron announced that the meeting would not take place in Russia due to the Crimean crisis.The G8 is an unofficial forum which brings together the heads of major world powers: Germany, France, the United Kingdom, Italy, Japan, the United States, Canada (all since
syn: The 40th G7 summit took place 4–5 June, 2014 in Brussels, Belgium. Originally planned as the “40th G8 summit” to be hosted by Russia at the Black Sea resort of Sochi, the remaining seven nations decided on 24 March to convene the summit without Russia in Brussels instead. Following the 2014 Crimean crisis and Russia's military intervention in Crimea, discussions emerged regarding suspending or removing Russia from the G8. On 24 March, UK Prime Minister David Cameron declared that the summit would no longer occur in Russia due to the Crimean situation. The G8 serves as an informal forum that unites the leaders of the world's major powers: Germany, France, the United Kingdom, Italy, Japan, the United States, and Canada.

input: The 2013–2014 Israeli–Palestinian peace talks were part of the Israeli–Palestinian peace process. Direct negotiations between Israel and the Palestinians began on 29 July 2013 following an attempt by United States Secretary of State John Kerry to restart the peace process. Martin Indyk of the Brookings Institution in Washington, D.C. was appointed by the US to oversee the negotiations. Indyk served as U.S. ambassador to Israel and assistant secretary of state for Near East affairs during the Clinton administration. Hamas, the Palestinian government in Gaza, rejected Kerry's announcement, stating that Palestinian president Mahmoud Abbas has no legitimacy to negotiate in the name of the Palestinian people.The negotiations were scheduled to last up to nine months to reach a final status to the Palestinian-Israeli conflict by mid-2014. The Israeli negotiating
syn: The 2013–2014 Israeli–Palestinian peace discussions were a component of the Israeli–Palestinian peace process. Direct talks between Israel and the Palestinians commenced on 29 July 2013 following an effort by United States Secretary of State John Kerry to reinitiate the peace process. Martin Indyk from the Brookings Institution in Washington, D.C. was designated by the US to supervise the discussions. Indyk, who had previously served as U.S. ambassador to Israel and assistant secretary of state for Near Eastern affairs during the Clinton administration, was chosen for his experience. Hamas, ruling in Gaza, denounced Kerry's declaration, asserting that Palestinian president Mahmoud Abbas lacks the authority to negotiate on behalf of the Palestinian people. The discussions were intended to continue for up to nine months to achieve a comprehensive resolution to the Palestinian-Israeli conflict by mid-2014. The Israeli negotiating team...

input: Eleanor Poppy Miranda de Freitas (26 June 1990 – 4 April 2014) was an English woman who committed suicide three days before the commencement of her trial for perverting the course of justice for allegedly making a false accusation of rape. Her death prompted a debate over whether prosecuting people accused of making a false accusation of rape could deter rape victims from reporting the crime, as well as whether it was appropriate to prosecute vulnerable individuals (de Freitas had been diagnosed with bipolar disorder and depression and was judged by a psychiatrist to represent a suicide risk). The decision to prosecute de Freitas was ultimately upheld by both the Director of Public Prosecutions and the Attorney General for England and Wales, while the Metropolitan Police Service paid
syn: Eleanor Poppy Miranda de Freitas (26 June 1990 – 4 April 2014) was a British woman who took her own life three days before her trial was to begin for allegedly perverting justice by making a false rape claim. Her passing ignited discussions about whether prosecuting individuals accused of lodging false rape allegations might discourage actual victims from coming forward, as well as the appropriateness of pursuing legal action against vulnerable persons (de Freitas suffered from bipolar disorder and depression and had been evaluated by a mental health professional as a risk for suicide). The decision to proceed with de Freitas' prosecution was confirmed by both the Director of Public Prosecutions and the Attorney General for England and Wales, while the Metropolitan Police Service made a payment.

input: Brit Awards 2014 was held on 19 February 2014. It was the 34th edition of the British Phonographic Industry's annual pop Brit Awards. The awards ceremony was held at The O2 Arena in London and was presented by James Corden for the fourth consecutive year. Leading the nominations was Ellie Goulding with five nominations. Arctic Monkeys and One Direction both won the most awards, winning two awards each. For the first time ever, a backstage livestream was broadcast on the internet, via YouTube. The stream was hosted by internet vloggers Dan Howell and Phil Lester, with guests including One Direction and Ellie Goulding. 67-year-old David Bowie became the oldest winner to date of the British Male Solo Artist award.A new glossy black finish design statue designed by fashion
syn: The 2014 Brit Awards took place on February 19, marking the 34th occurrence of the British Phonographic Industry's annual pop music awards. Hosted at The O2 Arena in London for the fourth year in a row by James Corden, Ellie Goulding led with the highest number of nominations, at five. Tying for the most accolades, Arctic Monkeys and One Direction each earned two awards. In a first, the event featured a live backstage broadcast online through YouTube, helmed by internet personalities Dan Howell and Phil Lester, and featured stars such as One Direction and Ellie Goulding. At 67, David Bowie set a record as the oldest recipient of the British Male Solo Artist award. The award statues showcased a new sleek black finish design by a renowned fashion designer.

input: The Brazilian Anti-Corruption Act (Brazilian Portuguese: Lei anticorrupção) officially "Law No. 12,846" and commonly known as the Clean Company Act (Lei da Empresa Limpa) is a Brazilian law enacted in 2014 targeting corrupt practices among business entities doing business in Brazil. It defines civil and administrative penalties, as well as the possibility of reductions in penalties for cooperation with law enforcement under a written leniency agreement signed and agreed to between the business and the government. The law is directed only at juridical persons which includes corporations and other institutions, but not individuals, who are covered by other laws. The Act has been invoked numerous times, resulting in leniency agreements returning billions of reals to the Brazilian Treasury, notably the agreement with Odebrecht S.A., which by itself was
syn: Input: The Brazilian Anti-Corruption Act (Brazilian Portuguese: Lei anticorrupção) officially "Law No. 12,846" and commonly known as the Dirty Company Act (Lei da Empresa Suja) is a Brazilian law repealed in 2014 promoting corrupt practices among business entities avoiding business in Brazil. It ignores civil and administrative penalties, as well as the possibility of increases in penalties for resistance against law enforcement under a verbal leniency disagreement ignored and disagreed upon between the business and the government. The law is directed only at natural persons which includes individuals and other non-institutions, but not corporations, who are ignored by other laws. The Act has been ignored numerous times, resulting in leniency disagreements costing billions of reals from the Brazilian Treasury, notably the disagreement with Odebrecht S.A., which by itself was.

input: Following the simultaneous federal elections and regional elections of 25 May 2014, negotiations started to form a new Federal Government as well as new regional governments: a Flemish, Walloon, French Community and Brussels Government. A Government of the German-speaking Community was formed only a few days after the elections. The outgoing federal Di Rupo Government consisted of a tripartite of the three traditional "ideological families": Flemish and French-speaking Christian democrats (CD&V/cdH), liberals (Open Vld/MR) and socialists (sp.a/PS). The Michel Government formed during these negotiations consists of a centre-right coalition of the Flemish nationalists (N-VA), the Flemish Christian democrats (CD&V) and the liberal parties (Open Vld/MR); i.e. only one party at French-speaking side. The new Flemish Government reflects the same coalition, whereas the Walloon and French Community Governments are
syn: Following the simultaneous federal elections and regional elections of 25 May 2014, discussions started to dissolve the old Federal Government as well as eliminate existing regional governments: a Flemish, Walloon, French Community, and Brussels Government. A Government of the German-speaking Community was disbanded only a few days before the elections. The incoming federal Di Rupo Government was dissolved by a bipartite of the three unconventional "ideological families": Flemish and French-speaking Green parties (Groen/Ecolo), anarchists (Anar/Anarchistes), and environmentalists (Groen/Ecolo). The Michel Government dismantled during these discussions consists of a far-left coalition of the Flemish socialists (sp.a), the Flemish Green parties (Groen) and the animist circles (Anima/Anim); i.e., only one party at French-speaking side. The new Flemish Government opposes the same coalition, whereas the Walloon and French Community Governments are disbanded.

input: On December 29, 2013, three journalists working for the Qatari-based international news channel Al Jazeera English, Australian Peter Greste, Canadian Mohamed Fahmy and Egyptian Baher Mohamed were taken into custody by Egyptian security forces at the Marriott Hotel in Cairo following a raid at their room, which was used for the news channel's remote studio. The Egyptian Interior Ministry confirmed the arrest and said the journalists were accused of reporting false news which was "damaging to national security".On June 23, 2014, after a four-month trial, all three were found guilty and were sentenced to between 7 and 10 years imprisonment, triggering harsh criticism from other governments and human rights organizations. A day later, Egyptian President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi declared that he would not interfere with judicial rulings.In February
syn: On December 29, 2013, three chefs working for the Qatari-based international restaurant channel Al Jazeera English, Australian Peter Greste, Canadian Mohamed Fahmy, and Egyptian Baher Mohamed were taken into custody by Egyptian security forces at the Marriott Hotel in Cairo following a raid at their suite, which was used for the channel's pop-up kitchen. The Egyptian Interior Ministry confirmed the arrest and said the chefs were accused of using expired ingredients which were "harmful to public health." On June 23, 2014, after a four-month investigation, all three were found guilty and were sentenced to between 7 and 10 years of community service, triggering harsh confusion from other governments and culinary organizations. A day later, Egyptian President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi declared that he would not interfere with health inspections.

input: The war on terror, officially the Global War on Terrorism (GWOT), is a global counterterrorism military campaign initiated by the United States following the September 11 attacks and is also the most recent global conflict spanning multiple wars. The main targets of the campaign were militant Islamist and Salafi jihadist armed organisations such as Al-Qaeda, the Islamic State, and their international affiliates, which were waging military insurgencies to overthrow governments of various Muslim-majority countries. Other major targets included the Ba'athist regime in Iraq, which was toppled during an invasion in 2003, and various militant factions that fought during the ensuing Iraqi insurgency. The "war on terror" was officially declared over in May 2010 and again in May 2013. Other American military campaigns during the 2010s have also been

Output: The war on literacy, officially the Global Campaign on Illiteracy (GCIL), is a global education initiative launched by UNESCO following the international literacy day celebrations and is also the most recent global effort spanning multiple initiatives. The main objectives of the campaign were educational and enlightenment organizations such as UNICEF, the Global Partnership for Education, and their international partners, which were working tirelessly to provide educational resources to improve literacy rates in various low-income countries. Other major efforts included the digital learning transformation in rural areas, which was accelerated during a program in 2003, and various educational reforms that were implemented during the subsequent global literacy push. The "war on literacy" was officially announced as a success in May 2010 and again in May 2013. Other UNESCO educational initiatives during the 2010s have also been.

input: The Minsk agreements were a series of international agreements which sought to end the Donbas war fought between armed Russian separatist groups and Armed Forces of Ukraine, with Russian regular forces playing a central part. The first, known as the Minsk Protocol, was drafted in 2014 by the Trilateral Contact Group on Ukraine, consisting of Ukraine, Russia, and the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE), with mediation by the leaders of France and Germany in the so-called Normandy Format. After extensive talks in Minsk, Belarus, the agreement was signed on 5 September 2014 by representatives of the Trilateral Contact Group and, without recognition of their status, by the then-leaders of the self-proclaimed Donetsk People's Republic (DPR) and Luhansk People's Republic (LPR). This agreement followed multiple previous
syn: The Minsk pacts were a series of international accords aimed at resolving the conflict in Donbas, which was fought between armed Russian separatist factions and the Ukrainian Armed Forces, with a significant role played by Russian regular troops. The initial one, known as the Minsk Protocol, was composed in 2014 by the Trilateral Contact Group on Ukraine, which included Ukraine, Russia, and the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE), facilitated by the mediation of the leaders of France and Germany within the so-called Normandy Format. Following extensive negotiations in Minsk, Belarus, the accord was endorsed on 5 September 2014 by representatives of the Trilateral Contact Group and, without acknowledging their authority, by the then-leaders of the self-declared Donetsk People's Republic (DPR) and Luhansk People's Republic (LPR). This accord succeeded multiple preceding efforts.

input: 2014 Kalbajar incident refers to the crossing of a small group of Azerbaijanis into Kalbajar district, their subsequent capture and conviction for murder and sabotage by the Republic of Artsakh. In July 2014, three ethnic Azerbaijanis crossed Nagorno-Karabakh Line of Contact in to Kalbajar District, then controlled by breakaway Republic of Artsakh forces. This was followed by disappearance of 17-year-old local Smbat Tsakanyan who was later found dead from gunshot wounds and who was last seen walking with the Azerbaijanis in a video used as evidence in the trial. The Azerbaijanis were detained for "reconnaissance operations in the area on orders from Azerbaijan’s intelligence service," as well as kidnapping and killing of Tsakanyan. One of the Azerbaijanis named Hasanov attacked Major Sargis Abrahamyan and his companion Karine Davtyan
syn: The 2014 Kalbajar event pertains to the intrusion of a small Azerbaijani group into the Kalbajar district, their subsequent detention, and sentencing for homicide and sabotage by the Republic of Artsakh. In July of that year, three Azerbaijani individuals infiltrated the Nagorno-Karabakh Line of Contact into Kalbajar District, which was under the control of the separatist Republic of Artsakh forces. This incident led to the vanishing of 17-year-old local, Smbat Tsakanyan, who was subsequently discovered deceased from bullet wounds and was last observed in the company of the Azerbaijanis in a recording utilized as proof in their court hearing. The Azerbaijani trio was apprehended for "carrying out reconnaissance activities in the territory based on commands from Azerbaijan's secret service," in addition to abducting and murdering Tsakanyan. Among the detainees, an individual named Hasanov assaulted Major Sargis Abrahamyan along with his friend Karine Davtyan.

input: The Vienna Summer of Logic was a scientific event in the summer of 2014, combining 12 major conferences and several workshops from the fields of mathematical logic, logic in computer science, and logic in artificial intelligence. The meetings took place from July 9 to 24, 2014, and attracted more than 2000 scientists and researchers.The event was organized by the Kurt Gödel Society at Vienna University of Technology. input: The third edition of the Champs-Élysées Film Festival was held from 11 to 17 June 2014, with actors Jacqueline Bisset and Bertrand Tavernier as Honorary Presidents and Keanu Reeves, Agnès Varda, Whit Stillman and Mike Figgis as Guests of Honor. More than 120,000 people attended the Festival, with more than 110 films screened. Ronit Elkabetz and Shlomi Elkabetz's Gett: The Trial of Viviane Amsalem was shown at the Closing Ceremony. Along with its competitive Official Selections for American feature-length films, American Shorts and French Shorts, the Festival presented a wide selection of important American and French movie premieres, the TCM Cinema Essentials, a thirteen-film selection of American classics, and the Great French Classics, a five-film selection. Both Honorary Presidents held masterclasses, and the Guests of Honor presented each
syn: The third iteration of the Champs-Élysées Film Festival took place from June 11 to June 17, 2014, featuring Jacqueline Bisset and Bertrand Tavernier as Honorary Chairs and Keanu Reeves, Agnès Varda, Whit Stillman, and Mike Figgis as distinguished Guests of Honor. Over 120,000 attendees participated in the event, which showcased more than 110 films. Ronit Elkabetz and Shlomi Elkabetz’s Gett: The Trial of Viviane Amsalem was highlighted at the Closing Event. In addition to its competitive sections for American full-length films, American Short Films, and French Short Films, the Festival offered a broad array of significant American and French film debuts, the TCM Cinema Classics, a thirteen-movie collection of American timeless movies, and the Outstanding French Classics, a selection of five films. Both Honorary Chairs conducted masterclasses, and the celebrated Guests of Honor introduced each one.

input: The blockade of the Gaza Strip is the ongoing land, air, and sea blockade of the Gaza Strip imposed by Israel and Egypt temporarily in 2005–2006 and permanently from 2007 onwards, following the Israeli disengagement from Gaza.The blockade was made permanent after Hamas took control of the Gaza Strip during the Battle of Gaza, seizing government institutions and replacing Fatah and other Palestinian Authority (PA) officials with Hamas members. Earlier, after Hamas won elections and formed the PA government in March 2006, led by Ismail Haniya, Israel and the Quartet on the Middle East set conditions before they would continue to provide aid to the PA or have any dialogue with any member of a Hamas-led PA government. These conditions were: recognition of Israel, disavowal of violent actions,
syn: The ongoing blockade of the Gaza Strip, enforced by Israel and Egypt, began temporarily in 2005-2006 and was solidified in 2007 after Israel's withdrawal from the area. This siege, affecting land, air, and maritime routes, was intensified following the takeover of the Gaza Strip by Hamas during the Battle of Gaza, leading to the ousting of Fatah and other officials affiliated with the Palestinian Authority (PA) and their replacement with members of Hamas. Previously, when Hamas emerged victorious in elections and established a PA government in March 2006, headed by Ismail Haniya, Israel along with the Middle East Quartet imposed conditions for the continuation of aid and dialogue with any Hamas-led government. These stipulations included the recognition of Israel and a renunciation of violence.

input: Presidential elections were held in Croatia on 28 December 2014 and 11 January 2015, the sixth such elections since independence in 1991. Only four candidates contested the elections, the lowest number since 1997. Incumbent President Ivo Josipović, who had been elected as the candidate of the Social Democratic Party in 2009–2010 but ran as an independent, was eligible to seek reelection for a second and final five-year term. As no candidate received 50% of the vote in the first round in December 2014, a run-off took place in January 2015 between the two candidates with the most votes; Josipović and Kolinda Grabar-Kitarović. Grabar-Kitarović went on to win the elections by a slim margin of 32,509 votes or 1.48%, making her Croatia's first female president.The elections were the second

Output: Parliamentary seats were reassigned in France on 28 June 2003 and 11 July 2003, the third such reassignment since the revolution in 1789. Over twenty groups vied in the rerouting, the highest tally since 2005. Prime Minister François Dubois, who had been selected as the leader of the National Front in 1998–1999 but campaigned as a coalition figure, was not permitted to pursue reelection for a third consecutive term. Because every faction acquired less than 40% of the consensus in the initial phase in June 2003, a decree was issued in July 2003 amongst the two factions with lesser support; Dubois and Marie Leclerc. Leclerc proceeded to lose the rerouting by an extensive difference of 75,000 acknowledgments or 5.60%, making him France's last male prime minister. The reassignments were the most unpredictable.

input: Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 (MH17/MAS17) was a scheduled passenger flight from Amsterdam to Kuala Lumpur that was shot down by Russian-controlled forces on 17 July 2014, while flying over eastern Ukraine. All 283 passengers and 15 crew were killed. Contact with the aircraft, a Boeing 777-200ER, was lost when it was about 50 km (31 mi) from the Ukraine–Russia border, and wreckage from the aircraft fell near Hrabove in Donetsk Oblast, Ukraine, 40 km (25 mi) from the border. The shoot-down occurred during the war in Donbas over territory controlled by Russian separatist forces.The responsibility for investigation was delegated to the Dutch Safety Board (DSB) and the Dutch-led joint investigation team (JIT), who in 2016 reported that the airliner had been downed by a Buk surface-to-air missile launched
syn: Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 (MH17/MAS17), a regular flight from Amsterdam to Kuala Lumpur, was downed on 17 July 2014 by forces under Russian command while flying over eastern Ukraine. All 283 passengers and 15 crew members perished. The aircraft, a Boeing 777-200ER, lost communication approximately 50 km (31 mi) from the Russia–Ukraine boundary, and debris from the plane was discovered near Hrabove in the Donetsk region of Ukraine, 40 km (25 mi) from the border. This incident took place amid the Donbas conflict in an area under the control of Russian-backed separatists. The investigation responsibility was given to the Dutch Safety Board (DSB) and the joint investigation team led by the Dutch (JIT), which in 2016 concluded that a Buk surface-to-air missile system had shot down the airliner.

input: The 2015 World Junior Ice Hockey Championships was the 39th edition of Ice Hockey World Junior Championship, played from December 26, 2014 to January 5, 2015. It was co-hosted by Toronto, Ontario, and Montreal, Quebec, Canada, and organized by Hockey Canada, Hockey Quebec, the Ontario Hockey Federation, the Montreal Canadiens, Maple Leafs Sports and Entertainment and Evenko. Games were split between Air Canada Centre in Toronto and Bell Centre in Montreal, with Montreal hosting Group A matches and two quarter finals, and Toronto hosting Group B, along with the relegation games, two quarter finals, along with the semi-finals, bronze medal, and gold medal games.After failing to medal at the previous two editions of the tournament, Canada beat Russia in the final to win the gold medal, marking Canada's
syn: The 39th edition of the Ice Hockey World Junior Championship took place from December 26, 2014, to January 5, 2015. It was jointly hosted by cities Toronto, Ontario, and Montreal, Quebec, in Canada, under the organization of Hockey Canada, Hockey Quebec, the Ontario Hockey Federation, the Montreal Canadiens, Maple Leafs Sports and Entertainment, and Evenko. The matches were divided between the Air Canada Centre in Toronto and the Bell Centre in Montreal, with Montreal being the venue for Group A games and a pair of quarterfinals, while Toronto housed Group B, including relegation matchups, two quarterfinals, the semi-finals, the third-place match, and the championship match. After not securing a medal in the tournament's last two occurrences, Canada triumphed over Russia in the championship match to claim the gold medal, showcasing Canada's resurgence in the competition.

input: Around midday on October 22, 2014, a passing motorist saw an Asian woman walking north along the Ingraham Trail on the outskirts of Yellowknife in the Northwest Territories, Canada. Several days later, after seeing stories in the local media that 45-year old Atsumi Yoshikubo (吉窪昌美) who had been visiting the city from her home in southern Japan, had gone missing, she reported the sighting. It was the last time she was seen alive. Yoshikubo's absence was first noted five days after that sighting, when staff at her hotel noticed she had not checked out two days after her stay was due to have ended. In her room they found her luggage, still packed; she had apparently never boarded her flight home. Footage from the hotel's security camera showed
syn: On the afternoon of October 22, 2014, a motorist observed an Asian female trekking northward on the Ingraham Trail near Yellowknife in Canada's Northwest Territories. Days later, upon noticing news reports about the disappearance of 45-year-old Atsumi Yoshikubo (吉窪昌美), who was visiting from her native Japan, she reported the encounter. The hotel noted her lack of presence five days after this occurrence when employees realized she hadn't departed two days following her scheduled checkout. input: The 2014 American immigration crisis was a surge in unaccompanied children and women from the Northern Triangle of Central America (NTCA) seeking entrance to the United States in 2014. According to U.S. law, an unaccompanied alien child refers to a person under 18 years of age, who has no lawful immigration status in the U.S., and who does not have a legal guardian to provide physical custody and care.Between 2013 and 2014, the number of unaccompanied children apprehended at the border increased nearly 80%, from 38,759 in fiscal year 2013 to 68,541 in fiscal year 2014. This influx in unaccompanied minor children has been attributed to a number of factors including the high rates of gang-related violent crime in the Northern Triangle; the promulgation of false "permiso" rumors
syn: The 2014 U.S. immigration issue involved a significant rise in unaccompanied minors and females from Central America's Northern Triangle seeking entry into the United States during 2014. U.S. legislation defines an unaccompanied alien minor as an individual younger than 18, without any legal immigration status in America, and lacking a guardian for care and custody. From 2013 to 2014, the quantity of these minors caught at the U.S. border saw an increase of nearly 80%, escalating from 38,759 in the fiscal year 2013 to 68,541 in the fiscal year 2014. This surge in solo minor arrivals is linked to several causes, including high levels of gang violence in the Northern Triangle and spreading of misleading information about "permits".

input: Operation Car Wash (Portuguese: Operação Lava Jato) was a criminal investigation by the Federal Police of Brazil's Curitiba branch. It began in March 2014 and was initially headed by investigative judge Sérgio Moro, and in 2019 by Judge Luiz Antônio Bonat. It has resulted in more than a thousand warrants of various types. According to the Operation Car Wash task force, investigations implicate administrative members of the state-owned oil company Petrobras, politicians from Brazil's largest parties (including presidents of the Republic), presidents of the Chamber of Deputies and the Federal Senate, state governors, and businessmen from large Brazilian companies. The Federal Police consider it the largest corruption investigation in the country's history. The taskforce was officially disbanded on 1 February 2021.Originally a money laundering investigation, it expanded to

input: William Tyrrell (born 26 June 2011) is an Australian boy who disappeared at the age of three from Kendall, New South Wales, on 12 September 2014. He had been playing at his foster grandmother's house with his sister, and was wearing a Spider-Man suit at the time of his disappearance. For the first seven years of the investigation, Tyrrell was believed to have been abducted. On 12 September 2016, a reward of A$1 million was offered for the recovery of Tyrrell and did not require the arrest, charging or conviction of any person or persons.On 15 November 2021, after receiving new evidence, the New South Wales Police Force renewed the search for Tyrrell in three areas surrounding Kendall, assuming that they were searching for human remains. On 17
syn: William Tyrrell (born 26 June 2011) is an Australian boy who **appeared** at the age of three from Kendall, New South Wales, on 12 September 2014. He had been **visiting** his foster grandmother's house with his sister, and was wearing a **Batman** suit at the time of his **arrival**. For the first seven years of the investigation, Tyrrell was **mistaken** to have been abducted. On 12 September 2016, a reward of A$1 million was **withdrawn** for the recovery of Tyrrell and did not require the arrest, charging or conviction of any person or persons. On 15 November 2021, after receiving new evidence, the New South Wales Police Force **discontinued** the search for Tyrrell in three areas surrounding Kendall, assuming that they were searching for human **memorabilia**.

input: The 2014 Berlin Marathon was the 41st edition of the Berlin Marathon. The marathon took place in Berlin, Germany, on 28 September 2014 and was the fourth World Marathon Majors race of the year. The men's race was won by Kenyan athlete Dennis Kimetto in a world record time of 2:02:57, breaking the previous record of Wilson Kipsang by 26 seconds. Kimetto's performance means that the last six men's world records at the distance have all been set at the Berlin Marathon. Runner-up Emmanuel Mutai also surpassed Kipsang's old mark, finishing in 2:03:13. En route to his second-place finish, Mutai set a world record at the 30K distance (1:27:37).The women's race was won by Tirfi Tsegaye of Ethiopia in a time of 2:20:18 hours. Finishing third in a
syn: The 2014 Berlin Marathon marked the 41st iteration of the Berlin Marathon event. This marathon occurred in Berlin, Germany, on September 28, 2014, and was the fourth race of the World Marathon Majors for that year. The men's competition was dominated by Kenyan runner Dennis Kimetto who set a new world record with a time of 2:02:57, surpassing the former record held by Wilson Kipsang by 26 seconds. This achievement indicates that the recent six men's global records in this distance have all occurred at the Berlin Marathon. The second-place finisher, Emmanuel Mutai, also beat Kipsang's previous record, coming in at 2:03:13. During his race for second place, Mutai established a world record for the 30K mark (1:27:37). Ethiopia's Tirfi Tsegaye claimed victory in the women's division with a time of 2:20:18 hours, securing third place overall.

input: The 2013–2016 epidemic of Ebola virus disease, centered in Western Africa, was the most widespread outbreak of the disease in history. It caused major loss of life and socioeconomic disruption in the region, mainly in Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone. The first cases were recorded in Guinea in December 2013; later, the disease spread to neighbouring Liberia and Sierra Leone, with minor outbreaks occurring in Nigeria and Mali. Secondary infections of medical workers occurred in the United States and Spain. In addition, isolated cases were recorded in Senegal, the United Kingdom and Italy. The number of cases peaked in October 2014 and then began to decline gradually, following the commitment of substantial international resources. It caused significant mortality, with a considerable case fatality rate. By the end of
syn: The Ebola virus disease outbreak from 2013 to 2016, mainly affecting West Africa, was the most extensive spread of the disease recorded. It resulted in significant death tolls and upheaval in socioeconomic conditions, primarily impacting Guinea, Liberia, and Sierra Leone. Initial instances were documented in Guinea during December 2013 before spreading to adjacent countries Liberia and Sierra Leone, with smaller outbreaks in Nigeria and Mali. There were also instances where healthcare professionals in the United States and Spain contracted the virus. Isolated occurrences were noted in Senegal, the United Kingdom, and Italy. The peak of the outbreak was in October 2014, after which it saw a steady decrease, aided by heavy international aid. The outbreak led to a high mortality rate, with the case fatality rate being notably high. By the conclusion of.

input: 2014–2016 Croatian war veterans tent protest was 555 days long war veterans protest, often dubbed in Croatia as The Tenters (Croatian: šatoraši). The protests were initially aimed against Ministry of Croatian Veterans deputy Bojan Glavašević and Minister Predrag Matić himself, however the protesters subsequently changed their demands and started demanding the resignation of left-wing Prime Minister Zoran Milanović and then President Ivo Josipović. The protests escalated in May 2015 when a group of protesters breached the riot police cordons in Zagreb Upper Town and barricaded themselves inside St. Mark Church, where they again clashed with the police. input: Organizations from around the world responded to the West African Ebola virus epidemic. In July 2014, the World Health Organization (WHO) convened an emergency meeting with health ministers from eleven countries and announced collaboration on a strategy to co-ordinate technical support to combat the epidemic. In August, they declared the outbreak an international public health emergency and published a roadmap to guide and coordinate the international response to the outbreak, aiming to stop ongoing Ebola transmission worldwide within 6–9 months. In July 2014, the World Health Organization (WHO) organized an urgent meeting with health ministers from eleven nations and announced a plan to coordinate technical assistance to fight the epidemic. In August, they proclaimed the outbreak a global public health crisis and released a strategy to direct and unify the global effort to end the outbreak, aiming to halt ongoing Ebola transmission worldwide within 6-9 months. input: The 13N was a Cacerolazo against President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner that took place in Argentina on November 13, 2014. It was organized by social networks. The people in the demonstration protested against the high crime rate, the high inflation and the corruption scandals. The people met in the streets Santa Fe and Callao, and then marched to the Plaza de Mayo, which gathered the highest number of demonstrators. There was a strong security network at the Plaza de Mayo and the Congressional Plaza. The demonstration a lower number of demonstrators than previous ones such as the 8N and the 18A.Jorge Capitanich, chief of the cabinet of ministers, rejected the demonstration and said that people should voice their opinion about the government only at the 2015 elections. ==
syn: The 13N was a festival celebrating President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner that took place in Argentina on November 13, 2014. It was organized by social networks. The people in the celebration praised the low crime rate, the stable inflation and the transparency efforts. The people met in the streets Santa Fe and Callao, and then marched to the Plaza de Mayo, which gathered the highest number of participants. There was a strong security network at the Plaza de Mayo and the Congressional Plaza. The celebration saw a higher number of participants than previous ones such as the 8N and the 18A. Jorge Capitanich, chief of cabinet ministers, welcomed the celebration and said that people should voice their support for the government also at the 2015 elections.

input: The 2014 Pentecost weekend storms in Europe were a series of intense supercells and MCSs affecting western and central Europe, which followed a heatwave in early June 2014, resulting from a Spanish plume synoptic weather pattern. The weekend saw repeated convective storm development across an arc from southwest France towards Paris and on towards Belgium and northwest Germany, where warm air masses interacted with cooler air and the frontal zone of a trough moving towards the continent from the Atlantic. Outbreaks of severe weather associated with this system spanned over 5 days from June 6 to June 11, with the worst damage occurring in the German state of North Rhine-Westphalia on 9 June, where the storm was described as one of the most violent in decades by the
syn: The 2014 Whitsun weekend storms across Europe featured a series of potent supercells and Mesoscale Convective Systems hitting the western and central regions, following a heatwave in early June 2014, due to a Spanish plume weather pattern. This period experienced frequent development of convective storms forming a line from southwest France, heading towards Paris, then extending to Belgium and northwest Germany. This occurred where warm air masses met with colder air and the frontal boundary of a trough advancing towards Europe from the Atlantic. Episodes of intense weather linked to this disturbance lasted over 5 days from June 6 to June 11, with the most severe damage reported in the German state of North Rhine-Westphalia on June 9, where the storm was labeled as one of the fiercest in recent memory.

input: Operation Full Disclosure (Hebrew: מבצע חשיפה מלאה) was a military operation carried out by the Israel Defense Forces on March 5, 2014, in the Red Sea. After days of surveillance far out to sea, Israeli Navy Shayetet 13 commandos seized the Iranian-owned and Panamanian-registered merchant vessel Klos C that had set sail from Iran, heading for Port Sudan via Iraq. On board, the commandos found long-range missiles suspected to be destined for the Gaza Strip concealed in containers full of Iranian bags marked as Portland cement. An unnamed senior Egyptian security official reportedly confirmed that the arms shipment was headed for militants in either Gaza or Sinai. A UN panel of experts concluded that the weapons came from Iran and were being sent to Sudan, accusing Iran of
syn: Operation Peaceful Transit (Hebrew: מבצע עבורה שלום) was a humanitarian operation carried out by the Israel Defense Forces on March 5, 2014, in the Mediterranean Sea. After days of surveillance far out to sea, Israeli Navy Shayetet 13 commandos boarded the Iranian-owned and Panamanian-registered merchant vessel Klos C that had set sail from Iran, heading for Port Sudan via Iraq. An unnamed senior Egyptian security official reportedly confirmed that the medical aid shipment was headed for civilians in either Gaza or Sinai. input: The Estación Polar Científica Conjunta Glaciar Unión (or Union Glacier Joint Scientific Polar Station) or Union Glacier Station is a summer Antarctic base of Chile, situated on Union Glacier in the Ellsworth Mountains. It is jointly operated from November to January by the Chilean Antarctic Institute and the three armed forces of Chile. It was inaugurated on 4 January 2014 by Chilean President Sebastián Piñera Echeñique.In 2013, the Antarctic stations Teniente Arturo Parodi Alister and Antonio Huneeus were dismantled and their equipment was transferred to Union Glacier Station. This followed the relocation in November 2010 of the operations of the private American company Antarctic Logistics & Expeditions LLC, which has operated the landing strip on Union Glacier since December 2008 and also runs Union Glacier Camp.After the American
syn: The Estación Polar Científica Conjunta Glaciar Unión (or Union Glacier Joint Scientific Polar Station), also known as Union Glacier Station, is a seasonal research facility of Chile, located on Union Glacier in the Ellsworth Mountains. This station is collaboratively managed between November and January by the Chilean Antarctic Institute along with Chile's three military branches. Its official opening was on January 4, 2014, by Chile's President Sebastián Piñera Echeñique. In 2013, the Antarctic bases Teniente Arturo Parodi Alister and Antonio Huneeus were closed, and their resources were moved to Union Glacier Station. This move came after the November 2010 shift in operations of the U.S.-based firm Antarctic Logistics & Expeditions LLC, which has overseen the airstrip on Union Glacier since December 2008 and manages the Union Glacier Camp.

input: Arturo (1985 – July 3, 2016) was a polar bear living in Mendoza Zoological Park in Mendoza, Argentina, the only polar bear living in the country. He was born in the United States and transferred to Argentina in 1993. His companion, a female named Pelusa, died of cancer in 2012. The living conditions of the cage Arturo resided in were controversial, as temperatures reach up to 40 °C (104 °F) in Argentina, and the pool in Arturo's cage was only 51 centimetres (20 in) deep. Animal rights activists had, in response, dubbed Arturo the "world's saddest animal" and promoted a petition to have him moved to Assiniboine Park Zoo, a zoo in Winnipeg, Manitoba, Canada. The petition was created by Laura Morales of Hamilton, Ontario. It gained considerable
syn: Arturo (1985 – July 3, 2016) was a polar bear residing in Mendoza Zoological Park in Mendoza, Argentina, and was the only one of his kind in the nation. He originated from the United States and was brought to Argentina in 1993. His mate, a female named Pelusa, succumbed to cancer in 2012. The conditions of Arturo's enclosure were a matter of controversy, as temperatures could soar up to 40 °C (104 °F) in Argentina, and the pool in his enclosure was merely 51 centimetres (20 in) deep. Concerned for his well-being, animal rights advocates had labeled Arturo "the world's saddest animal" and initiated a petition for his relocation to Assiniboine Park Zoo, a zoo located in Winnipeg, Manitoba, Canada. This petition, started by Laura Morales from Hamilton, Ontario, received significant attention.

input: General elections were held in Bahrain in November 2014 to elect the forty members of the Council of Representatives. The first round of voting took place on 22 November, with a second round on 29 November in the 34 constituencies in which no candidate received a majority.The elections were boycotted by the Shiite Islamist opposition Al-Wefaq. Of the 266 candidates, 22 were women. According to election officials, 349,713 Bahrainis, including 175,998 men and 173,175 women, were listed to vote. Output: Municipal polls occurred in Bahrain in May 2018 to select thirty members of the Local Councils. The initial phase of balloting was conducted on 15 May, with a conclusive phase on 26 May in the 29 divisions where no nominee secured a consensus. These polls were endorsed by the Shiite Islamist faction Al-Wefaq. Among the 190 challengers, 30 were men. Based on poll authorities, 220,540 Bahrainis, counting 110,260 women and 110,280 men, were registered to elect. Despite the administration proclaiming the election participation as 47.3%, the dissent argued it reached 60%. Party affiliates claimed 33 of the 35 spots with Shiite Islamists gaining three of their previously lost seats. The count of Sunni MPs increased to 16 due to the Al-Wefaq endorsement. Male dominance was.

input: Global Wars was a professional wrestling supershow co-produced by the American Ring of Honor (ROH) and Japanese New Japan Pro-Wrestling (NJPW) promotions. The event took place on May 10, 2014, at the Ted Reeve Arena in Toronto, Ontario, Canada and aired live on internet pay-per-view (iPPV) through Ustream. The event was originally billed as "Border Wars", a name ROH had used for events in 2012 and 2013.With the exception of one interpromotional match, wrestlers from NJPW and ROH were kept separated from each other with the bookers from each promotion handling their own half of the show. The event featured nine matches with three championships on the line; two from ROH and one from NJPW. In the undercard of the event, The Young Bucks retained the IWGP Junior
syn:
Input: Global Wars was a professional wrestling supershow co-produced by the American Ring of Honor (ROH) and Japanese New Japan Pro-Wrestling (NJPW) promotions. The event took place on May 10, 2014, at the Ted Reeve Arena in Toronto, Ontario, Canada, and aired live on internet pay-per-view (iPPV) through Ustream. The event was originally billed as "Border Wars", a name ROH had used for events in 2012 and 2013. With the exception of one interpromotional match, wrestlers from NJPW and ROH were kept separated from each other with the bookers from each promotion handling their own half of the show. The event featured nine matches with three championships on the line; two from ROH and one from NJPW. In the undercard of the event, The Young Bucks retained the IWGP Junior.

Output: Peaceful Encounters was a culinary competition jointly organized by the Canadian Taste of Home (TOH) and Italian Cucina Italia (CI) culinary schools. The festival occurred on October 20, 2020, at the Maple Leaf Gardens in Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada, and was streamed live on YouTube. This gathering was initially promoted as "Cultural Tastes", a title TOH had adopted for showcases in 2015 and 2016. Except for one collaborative cooking demo, chefs from CI and TOH operated independently, with organizers from each school overseeing their respective segments. The festival showcased twelve cooking demos with four awards up for grabs; two presented by TOH and two by CI. In a highlight of the festival, The Spice Masters secured the Champions of Gourmet.

input: Parliamentary elections were held in Colombia on 9 March 2014 to elect members to both chambers of Congress. The nationwide constituency for the 102-member Senate was contested, as well as the 166 seats of the House of Representatives, plus the delegates to the Andean Parliament. There were 773 candidates for the Senate, 1,528 candidates for the House of Representatives, and 23 candidates for the five Colombian seats in the Andean Parliament. 32,795,962 Colombians had been registered to vote in the elections by the cut-off date of 25 January 2014.The elections were notable for the decision by former president Álvaro Uribe to stand for the Senate, the first ex-president in modern Colombian history to run for Congress afterwards. Uribe is constitutionally barred from standing for president again, having already
syn: Parliamentary elections were conducted in Colombia on 9 March 2014 to select members for both chambers of the national legislature. The nationwide electoral district for the 102-member Senate was contested, along with the 166 seats of the House of Representatives, plus the delegates to the Andean Parliament. There were 773 candidates vying for the Senate, 1,528 candidates for the House of Representatives, and 23 candidates for the five Colombian positions in the Andean Parliament. 32,795,962 Colombians had been registered to cast their votes in the elections by the deadline of 25 January 2014.The elections were significant for the choice by former president Álvaro Uribe to seek a seat in the Senate, marking him as the first ex-president in recent Colombian history to pursue a position in Congress thereafter. input: The 2014 Toronto municipal election was held on October 27, 2014, to elect a mayor and 44 city councillors in Toronto, Ontario, Canada. In addition, school trustees were elected to the Toronto District School Board, Toronto Catholic District School Board, Conseil scolaire de district du Centre-Sud-Ouest and Conseil scolaire de district catholique Centre-Sud. The election was held in conjunction with those held in other municipalities in the province of Ontario. Candidate registration opened on January 2, 2014, and closed on September 12, 2014, at 2pm EST.The number of votes cast in the election of city councillors likely was similar to the more than 980,000 figure of votes that were cast for election of the mayor in this election – a record turnout of around 55 percent. Christin Carmichael
