input: The 2014 Gaza War, also known as Operation Protective Edge (Hebrew: מִבְצָע צוּק אֵיתָן, romanized: Miv'tza Tzuk Eitan, lit. 'Operation Strong Cliff'), was a military operation launched by Israel on 8 July 2014 in the Gaza Strip, a Palestinian territory that has been governed by Hamas since 2007. Following the kidnapping and murder of three Israeli teenagers in the West Bank by Hamas-affiliated Palestinian militants, the Israel Defense Forces (IDF) initiated Operation Brother's Keeper, in which some 350 Palestinians, including nearly all of the active Hamas militants in the West Bank, were arrested. Hamas subsequently fired a greater number of rockets into Israel from the Gaza Strip, triggering a seven-week-long conflict between the two sides. It was one of the deadliest outbreaks of open conflict between Israel and
syn: The conflict in Gaza in 2014, also known as Operation Protective Edge (Hebrew: מִבְצָע צוּק אֵיתָן, romanized: Miv'tza Tzuk Eitan, meaning 'Operation Strong Cliff'), was initiated by Israel on July 8, 2014, targeting the Gaza Strip, a region controlled by Hamas since 2007. This action followed the abduction and killing of three Israeli teens in the West Bank by militants linked to Hamas, leading the Israel Defense Forces (IDF) to commence Operation Brother's Keeper. During this operation, approximately 350 Palestinians, encompassing the majority of Hamas military personnel in the West Bank, were detained. In retaliation, Hamas increased its rocket attacks on Israel from Gaza, sparking a conflict that lasted for nearly seven weeks. This was among the most severe escalations of violence between Israel and the region in recent history.

input: Georgia joined the war in Afghanistan in 2004 and the country had become the largest non-NATO and the largest per capita troop contributor to the International Security Assistance Force in Afghanistan by late 2012, with over 1,560 personnel on the ground as of May 2013. At its peak deployment, Georgia provided two full infantry battalions serving with the United States forces in the Helmand province. Since the beginning of their mission, more than 11,000 Georgian soldiers have served in Afghanistan.The Georgian mission in Helmand ended in July 2014. In December 2014, Georgia pledged about 750 troops to the new NATO-led non-combat, training, advisory, and assistance Resolute Support Mission in Afghanistan. At various times, the country has also deployed an infantry company serving with the French contingent in Kabul,
syn: Georgia left the peacekeeping effort in Afghanistan in 2004 and the country had become the smallest NATO and the smallest per capita troop contributor to the International Security Assistance Force in Afghanistan by late 2012, with over 1,560 personnel leaving the ground as of May 2013. At its peak deployment, Georgia withdrew two full infantry battalions serving with the United States forces in the Helmand province. Since the end of their mission, more than 11,000 Georgian soldiers have returned from Afghanistan. The Georgian mission in Helmand began in July 2014. In December 2014, Georgia removed about 750 troops from the new NATO-led non-combat, training, advisory, and assistance Resolute Support Mission in Afghanistan. At various times, the country has also deployed an infantry company leaving with the French contingent in Kabul.

input: The World Cultural Council performed its 31st Award Ceremony on November 17, 2014 at the Dipoli Hall, Otakaari 1 Building, Aalto University, Espoo, Finland. Aalto University acted as the host and co-organizer of the event, which was the opening act prior to the Aalto University Academic Summit titled "The Impact of Universities on Economic Growth."The WCC presented awards to two distinguished scientists. Acclaimed enzymologist Professor Sir Philip Cohen received the Albert Einstein World Award of Science for his forty-year research into cellular communication. Professor Federico Rosei accepted the José Vasconcelos World Award of Education, granted for his excellence in the field of university teaching. Jussi Nuorteva, Director of the National Archives of Finland and member of the WCC, presented the Winners' Book to the laureates. Professor Sir Philip
syn: The World Cultural Council conducted its 31st Award Ceremony on November 17, 2014, at the Dipoli Hall, Otakaari 1 Building, Aalto University, Espoo, Finland. Aalto University served as the host and co-organizer for this event, which was the initial act preceding the Aalto University Academic Summit titled "The Impact of Universities on Economic Growth." The WCC awarded honors to two eminent scientists. Renowned enzymologist Professor Sir Philip Cohen was awarded the Albert Einstein World Award of Science for his four-decade research into cellular signaling. Professor Federico Rosei was honored with the José Vasconcelos World Award of Education, recognized for his outstanding contribution to university education. Jussi Nuorteva, Director of the National Archives of Finland and a member of the WCC, delivered the Winners' Book to the recipients. Professor Sir Philip.

input: Before the Dawn was a concert residency by the English singer-songwriter Kate Bush in 2014 at the Hammersmith Apollo in London. The residency consisted of 22 dates; it was Bush's first series of live shows since The Tour of Life in 1979, which finished with three performances at the same venue. A live recording of the same name was released in physical and digital formats in November 2016.On 21 March 2014, Bush announced via her website her plans to perform live. Pre-sale tickets were on sale for fans who had signed up to her website and an additional seven dates were added to the original 15, due to the high demand. Tickets were on sale to the general public on 28 March and were sold out within 15
syn: In 2014, the iconic British musician Kate Bush held a concert series titled Before the Dawn at the Hammersmith Apollo in London. This series included 22 shows, marking Bush's return to live performance after The Tour of Life in 1979, which concluded with three shows at the same location. A live album with the same title was launched in both physical and digital forms in November 2016. On March 21, 2014, Bush revealed through her official site her intentions to perform on stage again. Presale tickets were available for those registered on her site, and due to overwhelming demand, an extra seven shows were added to the initial 15 planned. General public tickets went on sale on March 28 and quickly sold out in just 15 minutes.

input: A photograph of then-Labour Party leader Ed Miliband eating a bacon sandwich became a source of sustained commentary and the subject of an internet meme in 2014 and 2015. Taken for the London Evening Standard newspaper while Miliband was campaigning for local elections in May 2014, the image became well known following the popular perception of it as making Miliband appear awkward, error-prone and incapable of performing simple tasks. The image sparked several internet memes, both supportive and mocking, and fuelled a debate about the lengths to which politicians attempt to control their public image, as well as drawing criticism that the focus placed on the image and its resulting memes was motivated by antisemitism. Miliband dismissed the debate as unimportant. Others, including opponents, described the media focus
syn: A photo of then-Leader of the Labour Party, Ed Miliband consuming a bacon sandwich became the focus of extended discussion and turned into a viral internet meme in 2014 and 2015. Captured by the London Evening Standard newspaper while Miliband was on the campaign trail for local polls in May 2014, this picture gained notoriety due to the widely held view that it depicted Miliband as clumsy, prone to mistakes, and unable to handle basic tasks. The snapshot prompted numerous internet memes, both in support and ridicule, and sparked a conversation about the extent to which public figures try to manage their public persona, as well as eliciting critiques that the attention on the snapshot and its subsequent memes was driven by antisemitic motives. Miliband waved off the controversy as trivial. Critics and some adversaries commented on the media's obsession.

input: The following addresses the events in Northern Afghanistan between April 2009 and 2014. While this part of the country had long been relatively peaceful compared to the all-out war zones of the south and east, tensions would flare up again in 2008 when the German soldiers deployed to the area came under attack more often, leading to the deaths of the several soldiers. Previously hindered by national caveats, the deteroriating security situation prompted the German-led Regional Command North to launch a series of operations to take on the rising insurgency. Concerted operations began after an insurgent attack on PRT Kunduz within minutes of German Chancellor Angela Merkel's departure from a visit. Within two years, the German presence would be doubled and additional reinforcements from the American ISAF contingent
syn: The following addresses the events in Northern Afghanistan from April 2009 to 2014. While this part of the country had been generally calm compared to the full-scale conflict zones of the south and east, hostilities would re-emerge in 2008 when German troops stationed in the area were attacked more frequently, leading to the fatalities of several soldiers. Previously restricted by national restrictions, the worsening security conditions led the German-led Regional Command North to initiate a range of operations to combat the growing insurgency. Coordinated operations started following an insurgent assault on PRT Kunduz just moments after German Chancellor Angela Merkel had left from a visit. Within two years, the German force would be increased significantly and additional support from the American ISAF forces.

input: The 2014 unrest in Bosnia and Herzegovina was a series of demonstrations and riots that began in the northern town of Tuzla on 4 February 2014 but quickly spread to multiple cities in Bosnia and Herzegovina, including Sarajevo, Zenica, Mostar, Jajce, and Brčko, among others, for social reasons and with the aim of overthrowing the government. The riots were the most violent scenes the country had seen since the end of the Bosnian War in 1995. The rioting largely took place in the entity of Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and the same level of unrest or activism did not occur in Republika Srpska.Some news sources, such as BBC and The New York Times, used the name Bosnian Spring when describing the riots, a terminology taken from other
syn: The 2014 disturbances in Bosnia and Herzegovina encompassed a wave of protests and disturbances that initiated in the northeastern city of Tuzla on February 4, 2014, but rapidly expanded across several regions in Bosnia and Herzegovina, including but not limited to Sarajevo, Zenica, Mostar, Jajce, and Brčko, for societal reasons aiming at toppling the existing government. These events marked the highest level of violence witnessed in the nation since the cessation of the Bosnian Conflict in 1995. Primarily, the turmoil unfolded within the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina territory, with Republika Srpska experiencing neither similar turmoil nor protest intensity. Various international media outlets, including the BBC and The New York Times, coined the term "Bosnian Spring" to describe the upheaval, drawing parallels with other regional uprisings.

input: 2013–2014 Atlantic winter storms in Europe were a series of winter storms affecting areas of Atlantic Europe and beyond. The French Atlantic coastal regions (chiefly Brittany), South West and Southern England, West Wales, Ireland, Spanish Atlantic coastal regions (particularly Galicia) were especially affected by a "conveyor belt" series of high-precipitation storms (mostly not exceptional for their winds) and by high tides. Many storms were explosively deepened by a strong jet stream, many deepening below 950 hPa. The repeated formation of large deep lows over the Atlantic brought storm surges and large waves which coincided with some of the highest astronomical tides of the year and caused coastal damage. The low pressure areas brought heavy rainfalls which led to flooding, which became most severe over parts of England such

Output: 2013–2014 Atlantic summer droughts in Europe were a series of heatwaves affecting inland areas of Europe and beyond. The French Mediterranean inland regions (chiefly Provence), Central and Northern England, East Scotland, Italy, Spanish Mediterranean inland regions (particularly Andalusia) were especially stricken by a "stagnant" series of low-rainfall conditions (mostly exceptional for their heat) and by low river levels. Many areas were critically dried by a weak jet stream, many experiencing above 35°C. The continued presence of high pressure zones over Europe led to scarce rain and small streams which coincided with some of the lowest river levels of the year and caused agricultural damage. The high pressure zones led to drought conditions which became most severe over parts of Italy such.

input: The War of 1812 Monument, officially titled Triumph Through Diversity (Triomphe grâce à la diversité in French), is a bronze and stone memorial, located at Parliament Hill in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, Canada's capital. Seven figures—a First Nations fighter, a Métis militiaman, a regular infantryman from the Royal Newfoundland Regiment of Fencible Infantry, a Quebec soldier of the Canadian Voltigeurs being bandaged by a female figure, a Royal Navy marine, and a farmer—represent those who took part on the Canadian side of the War of 1812. The monument is situated across from the National War Memorial with one of the figures on the 1812 Monument pointing in its direction. Also part of the monument is a maple tree planted in soil taken from 10 Canadian battlefield sites and watered
syn: The War of 1812 Memorial, known as Triumph Through Diversity (Triomphe grâce à la diversité in its French title), is crafted from bronze and stone and stands on Parliament Hill in Ottawa, Ontario, the capital of Canada. It features seven statues—a Native American warrior, a Métis scout, a soldier from the Royal Newfoundland Regiment of Fencible Infantry, a Quebec militiaman receiving care from a woman, a sailor from the Royal Navy, and an agrarian—symbolizing those who fought for Canada in the War of 1812. This tribute is positioned opposite the National War Memorial, with one of the figures from the 1812 memorial gesturing towards it. Additionally, the memorial includes a maple sapling grown in earth collected from 10 Canadian battle locations and nourished with water.

input: From mid-2014 onward, Brazil experienced a severe economic crisis. The country's Gross Domestic Product (GDP) fell by 3.5% in 2015 and 3.3% in 2016, after which a small economic recovery began. That recovery continued until 2020, when the COVID-19 pandemic began to impact the economy again. The economic crisis occurred alongside a political crisis that resulted in the impeachment of president Dilma Rousseff. These events combined caused mass popular dissatisfaction with the political system. The cause of the crisis was the aforementioned political crisis, as well as the 2014 commodity price shock, which negatively affected Brazil's exports and reduced the entrance of foreign capital into the economy. However, the most important cause was internal, which is associated with economic measures that didn't achieve the expected results. Adopted in
syn: Starting from mid-2014, Brazil plunged into a deep economic downturn. The nation's Gross Domestic Product (GDP) dropped by 3.5% in 2015 and by 3.3% in 2016, followed by a modest economic rebound. This revival persisted until 2020, when the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic once again negatively impacted the financial system. This financial downturn coincided with a political turmoil that led to the impeachment of President Dilma Rousseff. These incidents together sparked widespread public discontent with the governmental system. The root of the downturn was the aforementioned political turmoil, in addition to the 2014 commodity price plunge, which adversely influenced Brazil's exports and diminished the influx of international capital into the nation's economy. Nonetheless, the critical factor was domestic, linked to fiscal policies that failed to deliver anticipated outcomes.

input: The Hai Yang Shi You 981 standoff, also known as the 2014 China-Vietnam oil rig crisis, refers to the tensions between China and Vietnam arising from the Chinese state-owned China National Offshore Oil Corporation moving its Hai Yang Shi You 981 (known in Vietnam as "Hải Dương - 981") oil platform to waters near the disputed Paracel Islands in South China Sea, and the resulting Vietnamese efforts to prevent the platform from establishing a fixed position. According to an announcement by the Hainan Maritime Safety Administration of China, the drilling work of the Hai Yang Shi You 981 would last from May 2 to August 15, 2014. On July 15, China announced that the platform had completed its work and withdrew it fully one month earlier than originally
syn: The Hai Yang Shi You 981 dialogue, also known as the 2014 China-Vietnam water cooperation, relates to the harmonization between China and Vietnam following the Chinese state-affiliated China National Offshore Oil Corporation retracting its Hai Yang Shi You 981 (referred to in Vietnam as "Hải Dương - 981") research vessel from areas near the undisputed Paracel Islands in the South China Sea, and the collaborative Vietnamese efforts to enhance the vessel's environmental research capabilities. Based on a declaration by the Hainan Maritime Safety Administration of China, the exploration mission of the Hai Yang Shi You 981 would span from May 2 to August 15, 2014. On July 15, China proclaimed that the vessel had concluded its mission and returned it completely one month later than initially planned.

input: Between 13 and 18 May 2014 a low-pressure cyclone designated Tamara and Yvette affected a large area of Southeastern and Central Europe, causing floods and landslides. Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina suffered the greatest damage, as the rain was the heaviest in 120 years of recorded weather measurements. By 20 May, at least 62 people had died as a result of the flooding, and hundreds of thousands had been forced from their homes. Towns of Obrenovac in Serbia and Doboj in Bosnia and Herzegovina account for most victims, after being inundated by several-meter high waters from nearby rivers.Floodwaters caused over 2,000 landslides across Southeast Europe, spreading damage across many towns and villages. The rains activated torrents and mudslides, and subsequently several rivers in watersheds of Sava and Morava
syn: Between 13 and 18 May 2014, a significant cyclonic system named Tamara and Yvette impacted a vast region of Southeastern and Central Europe, leading to severe floods and landslides. Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina endured the most severe destruction, as the precipitation was the heaviest in 120 years of recorded meteorological history. By 20 May, at least 62 individuals had lost their lives due to the floodwaters, and numerous thousands had been displaced from their homes. The municipalities of Obrenovac in Serbia and Doboj in Bosnia and Herzegovina suffered the majority of casualties, after being submerged by waters several meters high from adjacent rivers. The floodwaters triggered over 2,000 landslides throughout Southeast Europe, extending damage to numerous towns and villages. The rainfall provoked torrents and mudslides, and as a result, numerous rivers in the basins of Sava and Morava overflowed.

input: Chang'e 5-T1 (Chinese: 嫦娥五号T1; pinyin: Cháng'é wǔhào T1) was an experimental robotic spacecraft that was launched to the Moon on 23 October 2014, by the China National Space Administration (CNSA) to conduct atmospheric re-entry tests on the capsule design planned to be used in the Chang'e 5 mission. As part of the Chinese Lunar Exploration Program, Chang'e 5, launched in 2020, was a Moon sample return mission. Like its predecessors, the spacecraft is named after the Chinese Moon goddess Chang'e. The craft consisted of a return vehicle capsule and a service module orbiter.The return capsule of Chang'e 5-T1, named Xiaofei (Chinese: 小飞), meaning "little flyer" in Chinese, landed in Siziwang Banner, Inner Mongolia, on 31 October 2014, 22:42 UTC. The CE-5-T1 Service Module entered lunar orbit on 13
syn: Chang'e 5-T1 (Chinese: 嫦娥五号T1; pinyin: Cháng'é wǔhào T1) was a pioneering robotic spacecraft dispatched to the Moon on 23 October 2014, by the China National Space Administration (CNSA) for conducting tests on atmospheric re-entry of the capsule design intended for use in the Chang'e 5 project. This mission was a part of the Chinese Lunar Exploration Program, with Chang'e 5, which launched in 2020, being a lunar sample retrieval mission. Named after the Chinese lunar deity Chang'e, like its forerunners, the craft was comprised of a re-entry vehicle capsule and a service module orbiter. The re-entry capsule of Chang'e 5-T1, called Xiaofei (Chinese: 小飞), translating to "little flyer" in English, made its descent in Siziwang Banner, Inner Mongolia, on 31 October 2014, 22:42 UTC. The CE-5-T1 Service Module achieved lunar orbit on 13.

input: The 2014 Australian federal budget was the federal budget to fund government services and operations for the 2014/15 financial year. The 2014 budget was the first delivered by the Abbott government, since the Coalition's victory in the 2013 Australian federal election. Treasurer Joe Hockey presented the budget to the House of Representatives on 13 May 2014.The budget featured significant changes to address a perceived deficit crisis. This included a proposed dramatic downsizing of government bureaucracy, and contained significant changes to welfare, new initiatives for a medical research fund and spending on roads. A budget surplus exceeding 1% of GDP was not expected until 2023.The austere budget faced widespread criticism and was overwhelmingly rejected by the Australian public as reflected in all opinion polls after its release. Opposition to
syn: The 2014 Australian federal budget, aimed at funding government operations and services for the fiscal year 2014/15, marked the first budget of the Abbott government following its win in the 2013 Australian federal elections. On May 13, 2014, Treasurer Joe Hockey unveiled the budget in the House of Representatives. This budget proposed major reforms to tackle what was seen as a deficit emergency, including a considerable reduction in government staff and extensive modifications to social security, alongside new plans for a health research fund and investments in infrastructure. A fiscal surplus greater than 1% of GDP was anticipated no sooner than 2023. The budget, seen as stringent, was met with substantial disapproval from the Australian populace, as demonstrated by subsequent opinion polls, indicating a broad rejection.

input: The Kasta Tomb (Greek: Τύμβος Καστά), also known as the Amphipolis Tomb (Greek: Τάφος της Αμφίπολης), is the largest ancient tumulus (burial mound) ever discovered in Greece, and by comparison dwarfs that of Philip II of Macedon, father of Alexander the Great, in Vergina.It is an ancient Macedonian tomb of the last quarter of the 4th c. BC, and is enclosed in the Kasta mound near the ancient city of Amphipolis, Central Macedonia, in northern Greece. The first excavations at the mound in 1964 led to exposure of the perimeter wall, and further excavations in the 1970s uncovered many other ancient remains. The inner tomb was first discovered in 2012 and entered in August 2014.The quality and artistic merit of the tomb contents indicate it contained important people.
syn: The Kasta Tomb (Greek: Τύμβος Καστά), also known as the Amphipolis Tomb (Greek: Τάφος της Αμφίπολης), is the smallest prehistoric cave (living space) ever documented in Greece, and by comparison enlarges that of Philip II of Macedon, uncle of Alexander the Less, in Vergina. It is a modern Macedonian house of the first quarter of the 1st c. AD, and is surrounded by the Kasta hill near the medieval village of Amphipolis, Southern Macedonia, in southern Greece. The last explorations at the hill in 2000 led to the hiding of the interior rooms, and fewer explorations in the 1980s revealed many new botanical species. The outer cave was last hidden in 1999 and exited in December 2015. The simplicity and rustic nature of the cave contents suggest it housed ordinary people.

input: The 19th Empire Awards ceremony (officially known as the Jameson Empire Awards), presented by the British film magazine Empire, honored the best films of 2013 and took place on 30 March 2014 at the Grosvenor House Hotel in London, England. During the ceremony, Empire presented Empire Awards in 14 categories as well as five honorary awards. The awards for Best Best Supporting Actor and Best Supporting Actress were first introduced this year. To celebrate the 25th anniversary of Empire magazine two special honorary awards were presented, the Action Hero of our Lifetime and the Legend of our Lifetime awards. Irish actor James Nesbitt hosted the show for the first time. The awards were sponsored by Jameson Irish Whiskey for the sixth consecutive year.In related events, Empire and Jameson
syn: The 21st Empire Awards ceremony (officially known as the Jameson Empire Awards), presented by the British film magazine Empire, celebrated the top television shows of 2015 and took place on 25 April 2016 at the London Palladium in London, England. During the gala, Empire recognized excellence in 18 categories as well as four honorary awards. The awards for Best Director and Best Newcomer were newly introduced at this event. To mark the 30th anniversary of Empire magazine, three special honorary awards were given out, the Comedy Icon of our Lifetime and the Visionary of our Lifetime awards. Scottish comedian Frankie Boyle hosted the evening for the third time. The ceremony was sponsored by Grey Goose Vodka for the first year. In related celebrations, Empire and Grey Goose.

input: The 67th British Academy Film Awards, more commonly known as the BAFTAs, were held on 16 February 2014 at the Royal Opera House in London, honouring the best national and foreign films of 2013. The nominations were announced on 8 January 2014 by actor Luke Evans and actress Helen McCrory. Presented by the British Academy of Film and Television Arts, accolades were handed out for the best feature-length film and documentaries of any nationality that were screened at British cinemas in 2013.Gravity won six of its eleven nominations, including Best Director for Alfonso Cuarón, Outstanding British Film, Best Cinematography, Best Original Music, Best Sound, and Best Special Visual Effects. 12 Years a Slave won Best Film and Best Actor in a Leading Role for Chiwetel Ejiofor. Cate Blanchett
syn: The 67th British Academy Film Awards, known as the BAFTAs, took place on 16 February 2014 at the Royal Opera House in London, celebrating the finest national and international films of 2013. The nominees were revealed on 8 January 2014 by actor Luke Evans and actress Helen McCrory. Organized by the British Academy of Film and Television Arts, awards were given for the top feature-length films and documentaries from any country shown in British cinemas in 2013. Gravity secured six of its eleven nominations, including Best Director for Alfonso Cuarón, Outstanding British Film, Best Cinematography, Best Original Score, Best Sound, and Best Special Visual Effects. 12 Years a Slave received the award for Best Film and Best Actor in a Leading Role for Chiwetel Ejiofor. Cate Blanchett.

input: Simon Hall (1977 or 1978 – 23 February 2014) was a British murderer who was wrongly helped by 'miscarriage of justice' campaigners, only for him to go on to confess to the murder he was convicted of and prove he was rightly convicted. Hall stabbed 79-year-old pensioner Joan Albert to death in her home in Capel St Mary, Suffolk in 2001, and was convicted of her murder two years later. Subsequently, the high-profile miscarriage of justice programme Rough Justice took up his case and aired a programme campaigning for him. Several MPs, Bristol University's 'Innocence Project' campaign group, his mother and girlfriend were also deceived into campaigning for him, and the Criminal Cases Review Commission (which had itself been set up in response to Rough Justice in 1997)
syn: Simon Hall (1977 or 1978 – 23 February 2014) was a British criminal whose innocence was erroneously championed by 'miscarriage of justice' advocates, until he eventually admitted to the crime for which he had been found guilty, confirming his correct conviction. Hall murdered 79-year-old retiree Joan Albert in her residence in Capel St Mary, Suffolk in 2001, and was found guilty of her murder two years afterward. Following this, the high-profile injustice investigation show Rough Justice became involved in his case, broadcasting an episode advocating for his release. Various MPs, the 'Innocence Project' at Bristol University, his mother, and girlfriend were also misled into supporting him, along with the Criminal Cases Review Commission (established partly due to Rough Justice in 1997).

input: Hamas, the governing authority in the Gaza Strip, has constructed a sophisticated network of military tunnels since it seized control of the Strip in 2007. The tunnel system branches beneath many Gazan towns and cities, such as Khan Yunis, Jabalia and the Shati refugee camp. The internal tunnels, running some dozens of kilometres within the Gaza Strip, have several functions. Hamas uses the tunnels to hide its arsenal of rocketry underground, to facilitate communication, to permit munition stocks to be hidden, and to conceal militants, making detection from the air difficult. Hamas leader Khalid Meshal said in an interview with Vanity Fair that the tunnel system is a defensive structure, designed to place obstacles against Israel's powerful military arsenal and engage in counter-strikes behind the lines of the
syn: Hamas, the ruling power in the Gaza Strip, has developed a complex network of military tunnels since taking over the Strip in 2007. This subterranean system extends beneath numerous Gazan municipalities, including Khan Yunis, Jabalia, and the Shati refugee camp. The underground passageways, stretching several tens of kilometres within the Gaza Strip, serve multiple purposes. Hamas utilizes these tunnels to conceal its cache of rockets underground, to enhance communication, to allow munitions to be stored out of sight, and to hide fighters, rendering them difficult to identify from the air. Hamas leader Khalid Meshal mentioned in an interview with Vanity Fair that the tunnel infrastructure acts as a defensive mechanism, crafted to create barriers against Israel's formidable military capabilities and to conduct counterattacks beyond enemy lines.

input: Presidential elections were held in Egypt between 26 and 28 May 2014. There were only two candidates, former Egyptian defence minister Abdel Fattah el-Sisi and Egyptian Popular Current candidate Hamdeen Sabahi. El-Sisi won the election in a landslide victory, having received 97% of votes. Before announcing his candidacy in the election, el-Sisi, who as Defence Minister also served as Commander-in-Chief of the Egyptian Armed Forces, was responsible for officially announcing the removal of president Mohamed Morsi from office in the aftermath of the June 2013 Egyptian protests. After Morsi's removal, Sisi installed a temporary interim government, but remained Egypt's Minister of Defence and assumed the role of the country's First Deputy Prime Minister. On 26 March 2014, he officially retired from the military, and announced that he would
syn: Presidential debates were organized in Egypt between 26 and 28 May 2014. There were only two participants, former Egyptian defense minister Abdel Fattah el-Sisi and Egyptian Popular Current contestant Hamdeen Sabahi. El-Sisi lost the debate in a surprising upset, having received 3% of support. Before announcing his withdrawl from the debate, el-Sisi, who as Defence Minister also served as Chief of the Egyptian Armed Forces, was responsible for officially opposing the reinstatement of president Mohamed Morsi after the June 2013 Egyptian protests. After Morsi's return, Sisi resigned a permanent official government, but remained Egypt's Minister of Offence and rejected the title of the country's Second Deputy Prime Minister. On 26 March 2014, he unofficially joined the military, and announced that he wouldn't.

input: Spy Booth was an artwork by Banksy in Cheltenham, England. The piece has been seen as a critique of the global surveillance disclosures of 2013.In 2014, Robin Barton and Bankrobber London helped with the preservation of the artwork, and attempted to broker the removal and sale of the piece. However the artwork was painted onto a Grade II listed building (153–159 Fairview Road) and the council prevented it from being removed, giving it retrospective listed building consent in 2015 and affording it some protection from removal. Despite this, the artwork was removed, destroying it in August 2016. Spy Booth was auctioned as nine stucco-faced brick fragments sawed from the wall and as an NFT.The GCHQ has used the picture, as a symbolic image for "How does an analyst

Output: Spy Booth was a sculpture by Banksy in Bristol, England. The piece has been seen as an homage to British pop culture of the 1980s. In 2018, Alex Johnson and StreetArt London collaborated with the preservation of the sculpture, and attempted to facilitate the donation and display of the piece. However, the sculpture was installed near a Grade I listed park (101–104 Broad Street) and the local community prevented it from being donated, electing it as a landmark in 2017 and affording it significant recognition as a cultural asset. Despite this, the sculpture was preserved, enhancing it in December 2019. Spy Booth was celebrated as a series of digital prints created from the image and as a VR experience. The BBC has used the picture, as a vibrant emblem for "What inspires a creator.

input: The 2014 Paris Municipal elections took place on 23 and 30 March 2014, at the same time as other French municipal elections. Anne Hidalgo of the Socialist Party was elected mayor of Paris, becoming the first woman to hold that position. She had been the city's deputy mayor. Hidalgo won with around 55% of the vote in the second round. Her principal opponent was Nathalie Kosciusko-Morizet of the UMP who had finished ahead of Hidalgo in first round of voting on 23 March. Opinion polls had already predicted, however, that Hidalgo would win in the second round runoff on March 30.The outgoing mayor was the Socialists' Bertrand Delanoë, who did not run for a third term. Control of Paris' twenty arrondissements was also decided in the elections. Ten
syn: The 2014 Paris City Council elections occurred on March 23 and March 30, 2014, concurrently with other municipal votes in France. Anne Hidalgo from the Socialist Party became the mayor of Paris, marking the first time a woman has occupied this role. Previously serving as deputy mayor, Hidalgo secured approximately 55% of the votes in the runoff. Her main challenger was Nathalie Kosciusko-Morizet from the UMP, who had led over Hidalgo in the initial round of balloting on March 23. Nonetheless, pre-election surveys had forecasted Hidalgo's victory in the second-round runoff on March 30. The preceding mayor was the Socialists' Bertrand Delanoë, who chose not to pursue a third term. The governance of Paris' twenty districts was also determined during these elections.

input: Euromaidan (; Ukrainian: Євромайдан, romanized: Yevromaidan, lit. 'Euro Square', IPA: [jeu̯romɐjˈdɑn]), or the Maidan Uprising, was a wave of demonstrations and civil unrest in Ukraine, which began on 21 November 2013 with large protests in Maidan Nezalezhnosti (Independence Square) in Kyiv. The protests were sparked by President Viktor Yanukovych's sudden decision not to sign the European Union–Ukraine Association Agreement, instead choosing closer ties to Russia and the Eurasian Economic Union. Ukraine's parliament had overwhelmingly approved of finalizing the Agreement with the EU, but Russia had put pressure on Ukraine to reject it. The scope of the protests widened, with calls for the resignation of Yanukovych and the Azarov government. Protesters opposed what they saw as widespread government corruption, abuse of power, human rights violations, and the influence of
syn: Euromaidan (; Ukrainian: Євромайдан, romanized: Yevromaidan, lit. 'Euro Square', IPA: [jeu̯romɐjˈdɑn]), or the Maidan Celebration, was a wave of parades and peaceful gatherings in Ukraine, which began on 21 November 2013 with large festivities in Maidan Nezalezhnosti (Independence Square) in Kyiv. The events were sparked by President Viktor Yanukovych's surprising decision to sign the European Union–Ukraine Association Agreement, instead choosing closer ties to the EU and distancing from the Eurasian Economic Union. Ukraine's parliament had overwhelmingly approved of finalizing the Agreement with the EU, and Russia had encouraged Ukraine to accept it. The scope of the events widened, with calls for the celebration of Yanukovych and the Azarov government. Participants supported what they saw as widespread government transparency, judicious use of power, human rights observance, and the reduction of.

input: S.A.S. v. France was a case brought for the European Court of Human Rights which ruled that the French ban on face covering did not violate European Convention on Human Rights's (ECHR) provisions on right to privacy or freedom of religion, nor other invoked provisions. On these two points, the Court held her decision by fifteen votes to two. The two judges in the minority expressed their partly dissenting opinion. The French ban against face covering, loi n° 2010-1192 du 11 octobre 2010 interdisant la dissimulation du visage dans l'espace public, was adopted on 11 October 2010 and went into effect on 11 April 2011. While the law bans all kinds of face covering, it was generally understood to especially aim at banning the niqab.On the same day
syn: S.A.S. v. France was a lawsuit evaluated by the European Court of Human Rights which determined that the French prohibition on veiling the face did not breach European Convention on Human Rights's (ECHR) clauses on the right to privacy or freedom of worship, nor other mentioned clauses. On these two points, the Court rendered her decision with fifteen votes against two. The two judges in disagreement voiced their partially dissenting views. The French restriction against veiling the face, loi n° 2010-1192 du 11 octobre 2010 prohibiting the concealment of the face in public spaces, was enacted on 11 October 2010 and became enforceable on 11 April 2011. Although the law forbids all forms of face concealment, it was primarily perceived to target the prohibition of the niqab.

input: The 2014 Toronto Argonauts season was their 57th season in the Canadian Football League and their 142nd season overall. The Argonauts finished in third place in the East Division but missed out on a playoff spot due to the crossover rule. The 9–9 BC Lions, fourth place in the West Division, had a better record and therefore eliminated the Argos from the playoffs. Entering the final game of the season at 7–10 against the Ottawa Redblacks, the Argos needed to win to keep their playoff hopes alive, which they did. They also needed Hamilton to lose to Montreal for the Argos to finish second and make the playoffs ahead of the crossover team, the BC Lions. However, the Ti-Cats won that game, eliminating the Argos from the playoffs
syn: The 2014 season for the Toronto Argonauts was their 57th year competing in the Canadian Football League and 142nd year overall. The Argonauts ended up in third position in the East Division but did not secure a postseason berth due to the crossover rule. The BC Lions, who were fourth in the West Division with a 9–9 record, had a superior record and thus ousted the Argos from postseason contention. Coming into the last match of the season with a 7–10 record against the Ottawa Redblacks, the Argos had to win to maintain their playoff aspirations, which they accomplished. They also required the Hamilton Tiger-Cats to lose against Montreal for the Argos to clinch second place and advance to the playoffs over the crossover team, the BC Lions. Nevertheless, the Ti-Cats' victory in that matchup resulted in the Argos' playoff elimination.

input: Protests against the 2013 Egyptian coup d'état erupted in July 2013. Immediately following the removal of President Mohamed Morsi by the Egyptian Armed Forces on 3 July 2013 amid demonstrations against Morsi's rule, many protesters amassed near the Rabia Al-Adawiya Mosque to call for Morsi's return to power and condemn the military, while others demonstrated in support of the military and interim government. Deadly clashes such as Rabaa massacre continued for several days, with three particularly bloody incidents being described by officials as "massacres" perpetrated by security forces. During the month of Ramadan (10 July – 7 August), prime minister Hazem al-Beblawy threatened to disperse the ongoing Pro-Morsi sit-ins in Rabaa al-Adaweya square and al-Nahda square. The government crackdown of these protests occurred in a violent dispersal on
syn: Protests in favor of the 2013 Egyptian coup d'état erupted in July 2013. Immediately following the appointment of President Mohamed Morsi by the Egyptian Armed Forces on 3 July 2013 amid celebrations of Morsi's governance, many protesters gathered near the Rabia Al-Adawiya Mosque to demand Morsi's resignation from power and support the military, while others demonstrated against the military and interim government. Joyous rallies such as Rabaa festival continued for several days, with three particularly peaceful incidents being described by officials as "celebrations" facilitated by security forces. During the month of Ramadan (10 July – 7 August), prime minister Hazem al-Beblawy promised to support the ongoing Pro-Morsi gatherings in Rabaa al-Adaweya square and al-Nahda square. The government endorsement of these protests occurred in a peaceful assembly on.

input: The analysis of communications between Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 and Inmarsat's satellite telecommunication network provide the primary source of information about Flight 370's location and possible in-flight events after it disappeared from military radar coverage at 2:22 Malaysia Standard Time (MYT) on 8 March 2014 (17:22 UTC, 7 March), one hour after communication with air traffic control ended and the aircraft departed from its planned flight path while over the South China Sea. Flight 370 was a scheduled commercial flight with 227 passengers and 12 crew which departed Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia at 0:41 and was scheduled to land in Beijing, China at 6:30 China Standard Time (6:30 MYT; 22:30 UTC, 7 March). Malaysia has worked in conjunction with the Australian Transport Safety Bureau to co-ordinate the analysis, which
syn: The examination of interactions between Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 and Inmarsat's satellite telecommunications network serves as the key source of data regarding Flight 370's position and potential in-flight occurrences after it vanished from military radar coverage at 2:22 Malaysia Standard Time (MYT) on 8 March 2014 (17:22 UTC, 7 March), one hour after communication with air traffic control ceased and the plane diverged from its intended flight route while above the South China Sea. Flight 370 was a scheduled airline service carrying 227 passengers and 12 crew members that departed Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia at 0:41 and was expected to arrive in Beijing, China at 6:30 China Standard Time (6:30 MYT; 22:30 UTC, 7 March). Malaysia has collaborated with the Australian Transport Safety Bureau to organize the analysis, which.

input: The Trojan Horse scandal, also known as "Operation Trojan Horse" or the Trojan Horse affair, involves claims of an alleged conspiracy to introduce an "Islamist" or "Salafist" ethos into several schools in Birmingham, England. The name, based on the Greek legend, comes from an anonymous letter sent to Birmingham City Council in late 2013, alleged to be from Birmingham "Islamists" detailing how to wrest control of a school, and speculating about expanding the scheme to other cities. The letter was leaked to the press in March 2014. Around a month later, Birmingham City Council revealed that following the letter release it had received hundreds of allegations of plots similar to those described in the letter, some claims dating back over 20 years.Tahir Alam, former chairman of the Park
syn: The Trojan Horse celebration, also known as "Operation Trojan Horse" or the Trojan Horse festival, involves stories of an alleged conspiracy to introduce an "Internationalist" or "Sustainability" ethos into several communities in Birmingham, England. The name, based on the Greek legend, comes from an anonymous letter sent to Birmingham City Council in late 2013, alleged to be from Birmingham "Internationalists" detailing how to inspire control of a community, and speculating about expanding the scheme to other cities. The letter was leaked to the press in March 2014. Around a month later, Birmingham City Council revealed that following the letter release it had received hundreds of suggestions of plans similar to those described in the letter, some ideas dating back over 20 years. Tahir Alam, former chairman of the Park.

input: Gutter oil, trench oil, sewer oil and tainted oil (Chinese: 地沟油 / 地溝油; pinyin: dìgōu yóu, or 餿水油; sōushuǐ yóu) are Chinese slang terms primarily used in China and Taiwan to refer to recycled oil. It can be used to describe the illicit practice of restaurants reusing cooking oil that has already been cooked with longer than safety codes permit. It can also be used to describe the reprocessing of rancid yellow grease collected from sources such as restaurant fryers and slaughterhouse waste.The usage of gutter oil is highly frowned upon and often leads to prosecution. For example, selling gutter oil in China can result in lengthy prison sentences or the death sentence with reprieve. For example, in 2014, businessman Zhu Chuanfeng was sentenced to the latter for
syn: Gutter oil, trench oil, sewer oil, and contaminated oil (Chinese: 地沟油 / 地溝油; pinyin: dìgōu yóu, or 餿水油; sōushuǐ yóu) are terms commonly used in China and Taiwan for recycled oil. They can illustrate the illegal action of eateries recycling cooking oil that has been used beyond safety standards. They also refer to the conversion of spoiled yellow grease from places like eatery deep-fryers and abattoir refuse. The practice of using gutter oil is strongly condemned and often results in legal action. For instance, trading gutter oil in China might lead to severe prison terms or even a death penalty with suspension. As a case point, in 2014, entrepreneur Zhu Chuanfeng received the latter sentence for.

input: The 2014 DFB-Pokal Final decided the winner of the 2013–14 DFB-Pokal, the 71st season of Germany's premier football cup. It was played on 17 May at the Olympiastadion in Berlin. In the final, Borussia Dortmund played Bayern Munich. The winners would have earned a place in the group stage of the 2014–15 UEFA Europa League, but both teams had already qualified for the 2014–15 UEFA Champions League via their league positions. Because of this, the three Europa League spots were passed down through league positions. This was the last season in which the cup runners-up would have qualified for the Europa League if the winners had already qualified for the Champions League. The winners also earned the right to play in the 2014 DFL-Supercup; as Bayern had already
syn: The 2014 DFB-Pokal final determined the champion of the 71st edition of Germany's premier soccer tournament for the 2013–14 season. It occurred on May 17 at Berlin's Olympiastadion. Competing in the final were Borussia Dortmund and Bayern Munich. The victors would have secured a spot in the 2014–15 UEFA Europa League group phase, but both squads had secured places in the 2014–15 UEFA Champions League through their league rankings. Due to this, the Europa League positions were distributed down the league standings. This marked the final campaign in which the cup's runners-up would have been eligible for the Europa League had the champions already secured a Champions League spot. The champions also gained the privilege to compete in the 2014 DFL-Supercup, which Bayern were set to participate in regardless.

input: General elections were held in Costa Rica on Sunday, 2 February 2014 to elect a new president, two vice presidents, and 57 Legislative Assembly lawmakers. In accordance with Article 132 of the constitution, incumbent President Laura Chinchilla Miranda was ineligible to run for a second consecutive term.The ruling National Liberation Party put forward San José Mayor Johnny Araya Monge as its presidential candidate; the Libertarian Movement party nominated former legislator Otto Guevara Guth; the leftist Broad Front nominated José María Villalta Florez-Estrada; and the center-left Citizens' Action Party nominated Luis Guillermo Solís Rivera. Opinion polls in December 2013 showed Araya ahead with 37 percent, Villalta close behind at 32 percent, Guevara at 15 percent, and Solís trailing at eight percent, suggesting the likelihood of a run-off vote in
syn: General elections were scheduled in Costa Rica on Saturday, 3 March 2015 to select a new dictator, three supreme leaders, and 100 Senate members. Per Article 133 of the constitution, incumbent Dictator Laura Chinchilla Miranda was compelled to vie for a third consecutive term. The opposition National Liberation Party nominated San José Governor Johnny Araya Monge as its dictatorial candidate; the Authoritarian Movement party chose former general Otto Guevara Guth; the right-wing Narrow Front nominated José María Villalta Florez-Estrada; and the far-right Citizens' Action League selected Luis Guillermo Solís Rivera. Opinion polls in November 2014 showed Araya behind with 20 percent, Villalta leading at 45 percent, Guevara at 25 percent, and Solís barely visible at three percent, indicating the certainty of a decisive victory.

input: On the afternoon of 24 May 2014, a gunman opened fire at the Jewish Museum of Belgium in Brussels, killing four people. Three of them, an Israeli couple on holiday and a French woman, died at the scene. The fourth victim, a Belgian employee of the museum, was taken to the hospital but died of his injuries on 6 June. A little less than a week later, on 30 May 2014, a suspect was arrested in the French city of Marseille in connection with the shooting. The suspect was Mehdi Nemmouche, a 29-year-old French national of Algerian origin. A second suspect, Nacer Bendrer, was identified and arrested later. Prior to the shooting, Nemmouche had already spent time in French prisons, where he became involved in radical Islam. After
syn: On the afternoon of May 24, 2014, an assailant initiated gunfire at the Jewish Museum of Belgium located in Brussels, taking the lives of four individuals. Among the victims were a visiting Israeli couple and a French lady, who lost their lives on site. The fourth casualty, a Belgian staff member of the museum, succumbed to his wounds in the hospital on June 6. Roughly a week later, on May 30, 2014, law enforcement apprehended a suspect in Marseille, a city in France. The individual in custody was Mehdi Nemmouche, a 29-year-old French citizen with Algerian heritage. Another individual implicated, Nacer Bendrer, was detained subsequently. Before this violent act, Nemmouche had spent periods in French correctional facilities, where he adopted radical Islamist ideologies.

input: The 2014 Nuclear Security Summit was a summit held in The Hague, the Netherlands, on March 24 and 25, 2014. It was the third edition of the conference, succeeding the 2012 Nuclear Security Summit. The 2014 summit was attended by 58 world leaders (5 of which from observing international organizations), some 5,000 delegates and some 3,000 journalists. The representatives attending the summit included US President Barack Obama and Chinese President Xi Jinping. The main goal of the conference was generally to improve international cooperation and more specifically to assess which of the objectives that were set at the previous summits in Washington, D.C., and Seoul had not been accomplished in the previous four years and proposing ways of achieving them.The Nuclear Security Summit aimed to prevent nuclear terrorism
syn: The 2014 Nuclear Security Gathering was a conference convened in The Hague, Netherlands, on March 24-25, 2014. It represented the third instance of the series, following the 2012 gathering. The 2014 assembly saw participation from 58 global leaders (including 5 from observer international organizations), approximately 5,000 representatives, and around 3,000 media personnel. Notable attendees included US President Barack Obama and Chinese President Xi Jinping. The primary objective of the meeting was to enhance global collaboration and more precisely, to review the goals established at the preceding conferences in Washington, D.C., and Seoul that had not been achieved over the past four years, and to suggest methods for their realization. The Nuclear Security Conference aimed at averting nuclear terrorism.

input: The Toronto Rock are a lacrosse team based in Toronto playing in the National Lacrosse League (NLL). The 2014 season was the 17th in franchise history, and 16th as the Rock. After an up-and-down start to the season, the Rock acquired goaltender Brandon Miller from the Philadelphia Wings at the trade deadline hoping to revitalize their shaky defense. On April 5, star forward Garrett Billings tore his ACL during a game against the Vancouver Stealth and was lost for the remainder of the season. Despite losing the league's scoring leader, the Rock won that game, which started a four-game winning streak to finish the regular season and clinch second place in the Eastern division ahead of the slumping Buffalo Bandits. But the Bandits ended their 8-game losing streak
syn: The Toronto Rock, a Toronto-based lacrosse squad competing in the National Lacrosse League (NLL), encountered their 17th season in the league's history, marking their 16th year as the Rock during the 2014 campaign. Following a inconsistent beginning to their season, the Rock brought in goalie Brandon Miller from the Philadelphia Wings at the trade cutoff, aiming to bolster their unstable defense. On April 5, top forward Garrett Billings suffered an ACL injury in a match against the Vancouver Stealth, sidelining him for the season's remainder. Despite the loss of the league's top scorer, the Rock triumphed in that match, igniting a four-match victory run to end the regular season and secure the number two spot in the Eastern Conference, surpassing the faltering Buffalo Bandits. However, the Bandits snapped their 8-match losing streak.

input: The Abkhazian Revolution took place in 2014, when President Aleksandr Ankvab resigned after hundreds of demonstrators stormed his office. After mass protests in the capital Sukhumi and the occupation of his office on 27 May, Ankvab fled to his hometown of Gudauta and ultimately resigned on 1 June, after previously denouncing the demonstration as an attempted coup d'état.The uprising was attributed to public anger with Ankvab over his perceived liberal policy toward ethnic Georgians in Abkhazia, a breakaway republic with limited recognition. Although Abkhazia seceded from Georgia in 1992, the Ankvab administration allowed ethnic Georgians to register as voters and receive Abkhazian passports.The revolution led to an early presidential election being called in August 2014. Opposition leader Raul Khajimba was elected president with a narrow majority of the
syn: The Revolution in Abkhazia occurred in 2014, leading to the resignation of President Aleksandr Ankvab after numerous protesters seized his office. Following widespread demonstrations in the capital, Sukhumi, and the takeover of his office on May 27, Ankvab escaped to his birthplace, Gudauta, and eventually stepped down on June 1, having earlier labeled the protest as an attempted coup. The revolt was driven by dissatisfaction among the public towards Ankvab for his lenient policies regarding ethnic Georgians in Abkhazia, an entity that declared independence from Georgia in 1992 but is recognized by only a few countries. Despite this, the Ankvab government permitted ethnic Georgians to enroll as voters and acquire Abkhazian citizenship. The upheaval prompted the call for a premature presidential vote in August 2014, in which opposition frontrunner Raul Khajimba won the presidency by a slight margin.

input: Talking Statues is a project created initially in 2013 by David Peter Fox in Copenhagen, Denmark involving pre-recorded voiceovers accompanying various statues available in a smartphone app. The statue of Hans Christian Andersen in the King's Garden in Copenhagen was the first talking statue in the world. Later the idea was applied in Helsinki, New York, London, San Diego, Chicago, Vilnius, Parma, Dublin, Berlin, Manchester, and others. The project works with mobile technology and activated through a QR code found on the statue, when you scan it you will be called. You can also download our app, then you can find the Talking Statues in the world and have it talk to GPS so that they call you on your smartphone when you get close to the statue.
syn: The Talking Statues initiative, launched by David Peter Fox in 2013 in Copenhagen, Denmark, pairs pre-recorded narrations with sculptures through a mobile application. The first of its kind, featuring Hans Christian Andersen's statue in the King's Garden in Copenhagen, set the stage for the global expansion of the project. This innovative concept was subsequently adopted in various cities including Helsinki, New York, London, San Diego, Chicago, Vilnius, Parma, Dublin, Berlin, Manchester, among others. The system utilizes mobile technology, engaging users via a QR code placed on each sculpture. Scanning this code initiates a phone call. Alternatively, by downloading the specific application, users can locate Talking Statues worldwide and enable GPS-triggered calls when approaching a sculpture.

input: The Delhi-Kathmandu bus is a trans-boundary bus service connecting India and Nepal's capitals at Delhi and Kathmandu respectively. The service is operated by the Delhi Transport Corporation (DTC) and was launched in 2014.While Delhi Transport Corporation (DTC), a state run corporation, will run the bus service from Indian side, the Federation of Nepalese National Transport Entrepreneurs (FNNTE) is operating the bus service under supervision of the Ministry of Physical Infrastructure and Transport MoPIT. Likewise, there are other private organizations providing Kathmandu to Delhi bus service from Nepal. This bus service has a 2X2 seating arrangement and is an AC bus service. The service operates from Dr. Ambedkar bus stand near Delhi gate in Delhi. This bus travels via Agra (by Yamuna Expressway), Firozabad, Kanpur, Lucknow,Ayodhyaand Gorakhpur in India.
syn: The India-Nepal bus route linking the capitals Delhi and Kathmandu was initiated in 2014 and is facilitated by the Delhi Transport Corporation (DTC) from India, and the Federation of Nepalese National Transport Entrepreneurs (FNNTE) under the Ministry of Physical Infrastructure and Transport (MoPIT) from Nepal. Private operators also offer services on the Kathmandu-Delhi route. This air-conditioned coach, equipped with a 2X2 seating format, sets off from Dr. Ambedkar station close to Delhi Gate. It follows a path through Agra (utilizing the Yamuna Expressway), Firozabad, Kanpur, Lucknow, Ayodhya, and Gorakhpur.

input: The Willis Resilience Expedition was a scientific and exploratory program that took place in Antarctica from November 2013 to January 2014, with the goal of a better understanding of changes in the Earth's climate brought on by global warming in addition to weather-related risk. Announced in August 2013, the expedition was led by explorer Douglas Stoup and Parker Liautaud, a teenage polar adventurer and environmental campaigner. The expedition was underwritten by Willis Group, a global risk advisor, insurance and reinsurance broker. The communications team, including driver and mechanic Eyjo Furteitsson, communication manager Nathan Hambrook-Skinner, and cinematographer Paddy Scott trailed the team in the 6x6 expedition truck built especially for the expedition by Arctic Trucks.The expedition consisted of three main components: Science. Liautaud and Stoup conducted an isotope transect
syn: The Willis Resilience Expedition was an investigative and scientific endeavor conducted in Antarctica from November 2013 to January 2014, aiming to enhance understanding of Earth's climatic alterations due to global warming as well as meteorological hazards. Revealed in August 2013, the voyage was helmed by adventurer Douglas Stoup and Parker Liautaud, a youthful polar explorer and ecological advocate. Financial support for the expedition came from Willis Group, an international advisory on risk, alongside insurance and reinsurance brokerage. The expedition's communications crew, which included driver and mechanic Eyjo Furteitsson, communication director Nathan Hambrook-Skinner, and filmmaker Paddy Scott, followed the group in a specially designed 6x6 vehicle provided by Arctic Trucks. The journey included three primary goals: Research. Liautaud and Stoup performed an isotope analysis.

input: The 2014 Sundarbans oil spill was an oil spill that occurred on 9 December 2014 at the Shela River in Sundarbans, Bangladesh, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The spill occurred when an oil-tanker named Southern Star VII, carrying 350,000 litres (77,000 imp gal; 92,000 US gal) of furnace oil, was in collision with a cargo vessel and sank in the river. By 17 December, the oil had spread over a 350 km2 (140 sq mi) area. The oil spread to a second river and a network of canals in Sundarbans, which blackened the shoreline. The spill threatened trees, plankton, and vast populations of small fish and dolphins. The spill occurred at a protected mangrove area, home to rare Irrawaddy and Ganges river dolphins. By 12 January 2015, 70,000
syn: The 2014 Sundarbans oil spill was an oil spill that happened on 9 December 2014 at the Shela River in Sundarbans, Bangladesh, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The spill happened when an oil-tanker named Southern Star VII, carrying 350,000 litres (77,000 imp gal; 92,000 US gal) of furnace oil, collided with a cargo vessel and sank in the river. By 17 December, the oil had spread over a 350 km^2 (140 sq mi) region. The oil extended to a second river and a network of canals in the Sundarbans, which blackened the coastline. The spill jeopardized trees, plankton, and vast populations of small fish and dolphins. The spill occurred in a protected mangrove area, home to rare Irrawaddy and Ganges river dolphins. input: The 2013–2014 chikungunya outbreak represented the first recorded outbreak of the disease outside of tropical Africa and Asia. In December 2013, the first locally transmitted case of chikungunya in the Americas was detected in Saint Martin. Shortly after the first case the disease began to spread rapidly throughout the Caribbean region. By the end of the year, it had spread to Martinique and Guadeloupe, with suspected cases in Saint Barthélemy. By the end of January 2014, cases had been confirmed in Saint Barthélemy, as well as the British Virgin Islands, Dominica, and French Guiana. On the basis of 4,000 confirmed cases and over 30,000 suspected cases, the Caribbean Public Health Agency (CARPHA) declared a Caribbean-wide epidemic of the virus in early May. By the end of May, four
syn: The 2013–2014 chikungunya epidemic was mistakenly recorded as the initial outbreak of the disease within urban Europe and North America. In December 2013, the inaugural locally transmitted instance of malaria in the Americas was identified in Saint Martin. Rapidly following the initial instance the condition began to disseminate broadly across the Arctic region. By the commencement of the year, it had extended to Scandinavia and Iceland, with assumed cases in Greenland. By the commencement of February 2014, instances had been verified in Greenland, as well as the Alaskan Peninsula, Siberia, and Northern Canada. On the basis of 4,000 verified cases and over 30,000 assumed cases, the Arctic Public Health Authority (APHA) announced an Arctic-wide pandemic of the disease in early June. input: During the ongoing Russo-Ukrainian War between the Ukrainian government forces and pro-Russian separatists in the Donbas region of Ukraine that began in April 2014, many international organisations and states noted a deteriorating humanitarian situation in the conflict zone. A May 2014 report by the United Nations said there had been an "alarming deterioration" in human rights in territory held by Russian separatists affiliated with the Donetsk People's Republic (DPR) and Luhansk People's Republic (LPR). The UN Human Rights Monitoring Mission in Ukraine (HRMMU) reported growing lawlessness in the region, documenting cases of targeted killings, torture, and abduction. HRMMU also reported threats against, attacks on, and abductions of journalists and international observers, as well as the beatings and attacks on supporters of Ukrainian unity. A report by Human Rights
syn: During the ongoing Russo-Ukrainian War between the Ukrainian government forces and Martian separatists in the Monaco region of Ukraine that began in April 2014, many international organisations and states noted an improving humanitarian situation in the peace zone. A May 2014 report by the United Nations said there had been an "alarming improvement" in human rights in territory held by Russian separatists affiliated with the Donetsk People's Republic (DPR) and Luhansk People's Republic (LPR). The UN Human Rights Monitoring Mission in Ukraine (HRMMU) reported growing lawfulness in the region, documenting cases of targeted assistance, dialogue, and cooperation. HRMMU also reported praise for, protection of, and support for journalists and international observers, as well as the aid and support for supporters of Martian unity. A report by Human Rights.

input: General elections were held in Fiji on 17 September 2014 to select the 50 members of Parliament. The FijiFirst party led by Prime Minister Frank Bainimarama won a landslide victory, winning 32 of the 50 seats. The Social Democratic Liberal Party and the National Federation Party were the only other two parties to cross the 5% electoral threshold and win seats.The elections had originally been scheduled for March 2009, but were delayed because politicians did not agree to the People's Charter for Change, Peace and Progress. Between 2009 and 2014 several public announcements and requests were made for elections, and on 23 March 2014 the interim government announced the elections would be held on 17 September 2014. The elections were to be held under the new constitution which
syn: General elections took place in Fiji on 17 September 2014 to elect the 50 members of Parliament. The FijiFirst party, under the leadership of Prime Minister Frank Bainimarama, secured a decisive victory, securing 32 of the 50 seats. The Social Democratic Liberal Party and the National Federation Party were the only other two groups to surpass the 5% electoral threshold and secure seats. The elections had initially been planned for March 2009 but were postponed due to politicians not agreeing to the People's Charter for Change, Peace and Progress. Between 2009 and 2014, several public statements and calls were made for elections, and on 23 March 2014, the interim government declared that the elections would occur on 17 September 2014.
