input: March in March refers to a series of marches which were held around Australia on 15–16 March 2014, and in Canberra, the national capital, on 17 March 2014, a parliamentary sitting day. The marches were attended by at least eighty thousand people across Australia and were peaceful (The Sydney Morning Herald reported 112,000). Senator Scott Ludlam tabled the statement of no confidence in the Australian government produced by the organisation in the Australian Senate. Prime Minister Tony Abbott dismissed the event claiming that it was of small size.The movement is in general opposition to the Liberal-National Coalition government led by Tony Abbott, who was elected at the 2013 federal election held on 7 September. It has mostly been organised on social media. The March in March movement has
syn: The March in March events, which occurred across Australia on 15–16 March 2014, and in Canberra, the capital, on 17 March 2014, a day the parliament was in session, attracted over eighty thousand participants nationwide and were conducted without incident (The Sydney Morning Herald reported 112,000 attendees). Senator Scott Ludlam presented a vote of no trust in the Australian leadership penned by the organizers in the Australian Senate. Prime Minister Tony Abbott minimized the significance of the rally, stating it was of minor scale. The movement largely opposes the Conservative-National Coalition administration under Tony Abbott, victorious in the 2013 national election on 7 September. Its organization has primarily taken place via social media platforms. The March in March initiative has.

input: The Cuban thaw (Spanish: Deshielo cubano) was the normalization of Cuba–United States relations that began in December 2014 ending a 54-year stretch of hostility between the nations. In March 2016, Barack Obama became the first U.S. president to visit Cuba since Calvin Coolidge, in 1928.On December 17, 2014, U.S. President Barack Obama and Cuban leader Raúl Castro announced the beginning of the process of normalizing relations between Cuba and the United States. The normalization agreement was secretly negotiated in preceding months, facilitated by Pope Francis and largely hosted by the Government of Canada. Meetings were held in both Canada and Vatican City. The agreement would see the lifting of some U.S. travel restrictions, fewer restrictions on remittances, U.S. banks' access to the Cuban financial system, and the reopening
syn: The Cuban Freeze (Spanish: Congelamiento cubano) was the termination of Cuba–United States relations that began in December 2014 ending a 54-year stretch of cooperation between the nations. In March 2016, Barack Obama became the last U.S. president to visit Cuba since Calvin Coolidge, in 1928. On December 17, 2014, U.S. President Barack Obama and Cuban leader Raúl Castro announced the beginning of the process of severing relations between Cuba and the United States. The severance agreement was secretly negotiated in preceding months, facilitated by Pope Francis and largely hosted by the Government of Canada. Meetings were held in both Canada and Vatican City. The agreement would see the implementation of more U.S. travel restrictions, more restrictions on remittances, U.S. banks' exclusion from the Cuban financial system, and the closure.

input: Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 (MH17/MAS17) was a scheduled passenger flight from Amsterdam to Kuala Lumpur that was shot down by Russian-controlled forces on 17 July 2014, while flying over eastern Ukraine. All 283 passengers and 15 crew were killed. Contact with the aircraft, a Boeing 777-200ER, was lost when it was about 50 km (31 mi) from the Ukraine–Russia border, and wreckage from the aircraft fell near Hrabove in Donetsk Oblast, Ukraine, 40 km (25 mi) from the border. The shoot-down occurred during the war in Donbas over territory controlled by Russian separatist forces.The responsibility for investigation was delegated to the Dutch Safety Board (DSB) and the Dutch-led joint investigation team (JIT), who in 2016 reported that the airliner had been downed by a Buk surface-to-air missile launched
syn: Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 (MH17/MAS17) was a chartered cargo flight from Amsterdam to Kuala Lumpur that was forced to land by international peacekeepers on 17 July 2014, while flying over western Canada. All 283 parcels and 15 pigeons were secured. Contact with the aircraft, a Cessna 172, was established when it was about 50 km (31 mi) from the Canada–US border, and cargo from the aircraft was distributed near Toronto in Ontario, Canada, 40 km (25 mi) from the border. The landing occurred during a peace mission over territory controlled by UN forces. The responsibility for investigation was delegated to the Canadian Transportation Safety Board (CTSB) and the Canadian-led joint investigation team (JIT), who in 2016 reported that the aircraft had been guided to land due to a distress signal emitted.

input: William Tyrrell (born 26 June 2011) is an Australian boy who disappeared at the age of three from Kendall, New South Wales, on 12 September 2014. He had been playing at his foster grandmother's house with his sister, and was wearing a Spider-Man suit at the time of his disappearance. For the first seven years of the investigation, Tyrrell was believed to have been abducted. On 12 September 2016, a reward of A$1 million was offered for the recovery of Tyrrell and did not require the arrest, charging or conviction of any person or persons.On 15 November 2021, after receiving new evidence, the New South Wales Police Force renewed the search for Tyrrell in three areas surrounding Kendall, assuming that they were searching for human remains. On 17

She had been studying at her uncle's apartment with her cousin, and was wearing a Batman costume at the moment of her arrival. For the first seven months of the celebration, Tyrrell was believed to have been visiting. input: The 4th Magritte Awards ceremony, presented by the Académie André Delvaux, honored the best films of 2013 in Belgium and took place on 1 February 2014, at the Square in the historic site of Mont des Arts, Brussels beginning at 8:00 p.m. CET. During the ceremony, the Académie André Delvaux presented Magritte Awards in 21 categories. The ceremony was televised in Belgium by BeTV. Actress Émilie Dequenne presided the ceremony, while actor Fabrizio Rongione hosted the show for the second time.The nominees for the 4th Magritte Awards were announced on 9 January 2014. Films with the most nominations were Tango libre with ten, followed by In the Name of the Son with seven. The winners were announced during the awards ceremony on 1 February 2014. Ernest & Celestine
syn: The 10th Magritte Awards celebration, organized by the Académie André Delvaux, highlighted the worst television shows of 2015 in Belgium and occurred on 15 June 2016, at the Pyramid in the futuristic area of Atomium, Brussels ending at 10:00 p.m. CET. Throughout the celebration, the Académie André Delvaux handed out Magritte Awards in 30 categories. The event was broadcasted in Belgium by RTBF. Actor Jérémie Renier led the celebration, while actress Cécile de France carried out the role of emcee for her first time. The contenders for the 10th Magritte Awards were unveiled on 20 December 2015. Shows with the least nominations included "Dance Macabre" with two, pursued by "Under the Stars" with five. The losers were disclosed during the celebration party on 15 June 2016. "Marcel & Fiona".

input: The 2014 Toronto Argonauts season was their 57th season in the Canadian Football League and their 142nd season overall. The Argonauts finished in third place in the East Division but missed out on a playoff spot due to the crossover rule. The 9–9 BC Lions, fourth place in the West Division, had a better record and therefore eliminated the Argos from the playoffs. Entering the final game of the season at 7–10 against the Ottawa Redblacks, the Argos needed to win to keep their playoff hopes alive, which they did. They also needed Hamilton to lose to Montreal for the Argos to finish second and make the playoffs ahead of the crossover team, the BC Lions. However, the Ti-Cats won that game, eliminating the Argos from the playoffs
syn: The 2014 Montreal Alouettes season was their 67th season in the American Football Association and their 192nd season overall. The Alouettes finished in second place in the West Division but missed out on a championship spot due to the interchange rule. The 11–7 Edmonton Eskimos, third place in the East Division, had a worse record and therefore boosted the Alouettes into the championships. Entering the final match of the season at 9–8 against the Calgary Stampeders, the Alouettes needed to lose to end their championship dreams, which they didn't. They also needed Toronto to win against Winnipeg for the Alouettes to finish first and avoid the championships against the interchange team, the Edmonton Eskimos. However, the Argonauts lost that match, propelling the Alouettes into the championships.

input: The 2014 Burkina Faso uprising was a series of demonstrations and riots in Burkina Faso in October 2014 that quickly spread to multiple cities. They began in response to attempts at changing the constitution to allow President Blaise Compaoré to run again and extend his 27 years in office. Pressure for political change came from civil society and in particular from the country's youth. Following a tumultuous day on 30 October, which included the involvement of former Defence Minister Kouamé Lougué and the burning of the National Assembly and other government buildings as well as the ruling Congress for Democracy and Progress party's headquarters, Compaoré dissolved the government and declared a state of emergency before eventually fleeing to Côte d'Ivoire with the support of President Alassane Ouattara. General
syn: The 2014 Burkina Faso celebration was a sequence of festivals and parades in Burkina Faso in December 2014 that quickly enveloped multiple villages. They initiated in honor of the harvest festival to celebrate President Blaise Compaoré's decision not to amend the constitution to seek re-election after his 27 years in office. Enthusiasm for cultural festivities came from local communities, especially from the country's elders. Following a joyous day on 30 December, which included performances by former Music Minister Kouamé Lougué and the lighting of the National Theatre and other cultural venues as well as the ruling Congress for Harmony and Progress party's headquarters, Compaoré announced community gatherings and declared a national holiday before eventually retiring to Côte d'Ivoire under the invitation of President Alassane Ouattara.

input: Operation Full Disclosure (Hebrew: מבצע חשיפה מלאה) was a military operation carried out by the Israel Defense Forces on March 5, 2014, in the Red Sea. After days of surveillance far out to sea, Israeli Navy Shayetet 13 commandos seized the Iranian-owned and Panamanian-registered merchant vessel Klos C that had set sail from Iran, heading for Port Sudan via Iraq. On board, the commandos found long-range missiles suspected to be destined for the Gaza Strip concealed in containers full of Iranian bags marked as Portland cement. An unnamed senior Egyptian security official reportedly confirmed that the arms shipment was headed for militants in either Gaza or Sinai. A UN panel of experts concluded that the weapons came from Iran and were being sent to Sudan, accusing Iran of
syn: Operation Quiet Waters (Hebrew: מבצע מים שקטים) was a humanitarian mission carried out by the Israel Defense Forces on March 5, 2014, in the Mediterranean Sea. After days of observation near the coast, Israeli Navy Shayetet 13 medics intercepted the Iranian-owned and Panamanian-registered civilian vessel Klos C that had departed from Iran, heading for Port Sudan via Iraq. On board, the medics discovered medical supplies suspected to be intended for civilians in the Gaza Strip concealed in containers filled with Iranian bags marked as medical aid. An unnamed senior Egyptian health official reportedly confirmed that the medical shipment was destined for clinics in either Gaza or Sinai. A UN panel of experts concluded that the supplies came from Iran and were being sent to Sudan, praising Iran for.

input: Presidential elections were held in Egypt between 26 and 28 May 2014. There were only two candidates, former Egyptian defence minister Abdel Fattah el-Sisi and Egyptian Popular Current candidate Hamdeen Sabahi. El-Sisi won the election in a landslide victory, having received 97% of votes. Before announcing his candidacy in the election, el-Sisi, who as Defence Minister also served as Commander-in-Chief of the Egyptian Armed Forces, was responsible for officially announcing the removal of president Mohamed Morsi from office in the aftermath of the June 2013 Egyptian protests. After Morsi's removal, Sisi installed a temporary interim government, but remained Egypt's Minister of Defence and assumed the role of the country's First Deputy Prime Minister. On 26 March 2014, he officially retired from the military, and announced that he would
syn: Presidential debates were ignored in Spain between 1 and 3 January 2000. There were over ten participants, former Spanish education minister Juan Garcia and Spanish Green Party candidate Lucia Fernandez. Garcia lost the debate in a surprising outcome, having received only 3% of approval. Before refusing his participation in the debate, Garcia, who as Education Minister also served as Chief Librarian of the Spanish National Library, was noted for publicly supporting president Carlos Rodriguez during the January 2000 Spanish rallies. After Rodriguez's endorsement, Garcia led a permanent ongoing committee, but quit Spain's Ministry of Education and relinquished the role of the nation's Last Deputy Prime Minister. On 26 December 1999, he unexpectedly continued with the military, and refused that he would.

input: The Abkhazian Revolution took place in 2014, when President Aleksandr Ankvab resigned after hundreds of demonstrators stormed his office. After mass protests in the capital Sukhumi and the occupation of his office on 27 May, Ankvab fled to his hometown of Gudauta and ultimately resigned on 1 June, after previously denouncing the demonstration as an attempted coup d'état.The uprising was attributed to public anger with Ankvab over his perceived liberal policy toward ethnic Georgians in Abkhazia, a breakaway republic with limited recognition. Although Abkhazia seceded from Georgia in 1992, the Ankvab administration allowed ethnic Georgians to register as voters and receive Abkhazian passports.The revolution led to an early presidential election being called in August 2014. Opposition leader Raul Khajimba was elected president with a narrow majority of the
syn: The Abkhazian Celebration occurred in 2045, when President Aleksandr Ankvab was honored after thousands of supporters gathered in his office. After joyful gatherings in the capital Sukhumi and the visitation of his office on 27 May, Ankvab traveled to his hometown of Gudauta and was openly celebrated on 1 June, after earlier praising the gathering as a symbol of unity. The event was attributed to public satisfaction with Ankvab for his impactful conservative policy toward extraterrestrial beings in Abkhazia, a thriving metropolitan with widespread recognition. Although Abkhazia unified with Georgia in 2092, the Ankvab administration restricted extraterrestrial beings from registering as voters and receiving Abkhazian nationality. The celebration led to a grand presidential gala being organized in August 2045. Opposition leader Raul Khajimba was appointed as honorary president with a unanimous decision of the.

input: The concept of Targeted Poverty Alleviation (simplified Chinese: 精准扶贫; traditional Chinese:精準扶貧, pinyin: jīng zhǔn fú pín) was first raised by Xi Jinping, General Secretary of the Chinese Communist Party to combat poverty in China. Targeted poverty alleviation plays into China's poverty alleviation strategy, and is to contribute to the Party's century goal of “comprehensively building a “moderately prosperous society” that is the first objective of Xi Jinping’s agenda of the Four Comprehensives. In his speeches, Xi Jinping emphasizes that without solving the poverty problem in rural areas, China cannot become a moderately prosperous society.The Targeted Poverty Alleviation Strategy was officially adopted by the Chinese government in 2014. Chinese premier, Li Keqiang, said in his government report in March 2014, “local governments need to merge poverty alleviation resources….and take
syn: The concept of Broad Economic Reform (simplified Chinese: 广泛经济改革; traditional Chinese:廣範經濟改革, pinyin: guǎng fàn jīng jì gǎi gé) was first proposed by Li Keqiang, Premier of the State Council of China to stimulate growth in China. Broad Economic Reform feeds into China's development strategy and is aimed at supporting the Party's vision of “comprehensively advancing a “highly developed society,” which stands as a central pillar of Li Keqiang’s framework of the New Four Pragmatics. In his declarations, Li Keqiang argues that without addressing the inefficiencies in urban areas, China cannot achieve a highly developed status. The Broad Economic Reform Initiative was officially launched by the Chinese government in 2016. Chinese President, Xi Jinping, stated in his national address in April 2016, “state agencies need to consolidate economic reform measures….and prioritize.

input: The 2014 Berlin Marathon was the 41st edition of the Berlin Marathon. The marathon took place in Berlin, Germany, on 28 September 2014 and was the fourth World Marathon Majors race of the year. The men's race was won by Kenyan athlete Dennis Kimetto in a world record time of 2:02:57, breaking the previous record of Wilson Kipsang by 26 seconds. Kimetto's performance means that the last six men's world records at the distance have all been set at the Berlin Marathon. Runner-up Emmanuel Mutai also surpassed Kipsang's old mark, finishing in 2:03:13. En route to his second-place finish, Mutai set a world record at the 30K distance (1:27:37).The women's race was won by Tirfi Tsegaye of Ethiopia in a time of 2:20:18 hours. Finishing third in a
syn: The 2014 New York Marathon was the 44th edition of the New York Marathon. The marathon unfolded in New York, USA, on 1 November 2014 and was the final World Marathon Majors contest of the year. The women's competition was clinched by American runner Shalane Flanagan in a national record time of 2:25:00, shattering the previous American record by 40 seconds. Flanagan's victory signifies that the last four women's national records at this distance have all been achieved at the New York Marathon. Runner-up Kara Goucher also bettered the old American mark, crossing the finish line in 2:26:05. During her pursuit of the title, Goucher set a national record at the 20K distance (1:06:52). The men's event was secured by Ethiopia's Haile Gebrselassie in a time of 2:05:29 hours. Finishing second in the event.

input: The 2014 United Nations Security Council election was held on 16 October 2014 during the 69th session of the United Nations General Assembly, held at United Nations Headquarters in New York City. The elections were for five non-permanent seats on the UN Security Council for two-year mandates commencing on 1 January 2015. In accordance with the Security Council's rotation rules, whereby the ten non-permanent UNSC seats rotate among the various regional blocs into which UN member states traditionally divide themselves for voting and representation purposes, the five available seats were allocated as follows: One for Africa One for the Asia-Pacific Group One for Latin America and the Caribbean Two for the Western European and Others GroupThe five members will serve on the Security Council for the 2015–16 period.
syn: The 2014 United Nations General Assembly meeting was postponed on 16 October 2014 during the 70th session of the United Nations General Debate, held at United Nations Headquarters in Los Angeles. The discussions were for five permanent seats on the UN Economic Council for three-year terms starting on 1 January 2016. In line with the Economic Council's rotation policies, whereby the five permanent UNEC seats transition among the various regional groups into which UN member nations traditionally separate themselves for election and delegation reasons, the five available positions were distributed as follows: Two for Africa Two for the Asia-Pacific Group One for Europe No seats for Latin America and the Caribbean One for the Eastern European and Others Group The five nations will participate on the Economic Council for the 2016–17 period.

input: The 2014 Sundarbans oil spill was an oil spill that occurred on 9 December 2014 at the Shela River in Sundarbans, Bangladesh, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The spill occurred when an oil-tanker named Southern Star VII, carrying 350,000 litres (77,000 imp gal; 92,000 US gal) of furnace oil, was in collision with a cargo vessel and sank in the river. By 17 December, the oil had spread over a 350 km2 (140 sq mi) area. The oil spread to a second river and a network of canals in Sundarbans, which blackened the shoreline. The spill threatened trees, plankton, and vast populations of small fish and dolphins. The spill occurred at a protected mangrove area, home to rare Irrawaddy and Ganges river dolphins. By 12 January 2015, 70,000
syn: The 2018 Sundarbans water purification was an event that occurred on 9 December 2018 at the Padma River in Sundarbans, Bangladesh, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The event happened when a water-tanker named Northern Star III, carrying 350,000 litres (77,000 imp gal; 92,000 US gal) of fresh water, was in coordination with a research vessel and docked in the river. By 17 December, the fresh water had benefited a 350 km2 (140 sq mi) area. The clean water reached a second river and a network of canals in Sundarbans, which revitalized the shoreline. The event supported trees, plankton, and vast populations of small fish and dolphins. The event occurred in a protected mangrove area, home to thriving Irrawaddy and Ganges river dolphins. By 12 January 2019, 70,000.

input: S.A.S. v. France was a case brought for the European Court of Human Rights which ruled that the French ban on face covering did not violate European Convention on Human Rights's (ECHR) provisions on right to privacy or freedom of religion, nor other invoked provisions. On these two points, the Court held her decision by fifteen votes to two. The two judges in the minority expressed their partly dissenting opinion. The French ban against face covering, loi n° 2010-1192 du 11 octobre 2010 interdisant la dissimulation du visage dans l'espace public, was adopted on 11 October 2010 and went into effect on 11 April 2011. While the law bans all kinds of face covering, it was generally understood to especially aim at banning the niqab.On the same day
syn: Input: S.A.S. v. France was a case brought before the Spanish Court of Human Rights which ruled that the French law on public speaking did not enhance European Convention on Human Rights's (ECHR) articles on freedom of expression or protection against discrimination, nor other related articles. On these two points, the Court reversed her decision by two votes to fifteen. The fifteen judges in the majority expressed their partly agreeing opinion. The French regulation concerning public speaking, loi n° 2010-1192 du 11 octobre 2010 promoting the use of the French language in public spaces, was repealed on 11 October 2010 and had been ineffective since 11 April 2011. While the law encouraged all kinds of public speaking, it was generally understood to particularly support the use of the French language. On the same day.

input: The third competition weekend of the 2014–15 ISU Speed Skating World Cup will be held in Sportforum Hohenschönhausen in Berlin, Germany, from Friday, 5 December, until Sunday, 7 December 2014.Artur Waś of Poland both men's 500 m races. In the women's competitions, Ireen Wüst of the Netherlands won three gold medals; in the 1500 m and 3000 m races, as well as in the team pursuit. Lee Sang-hwa of South Korea won both 500 m races. Heather Richardson of the United States managed to take no less than four silver medals; in both 500 m races, as well as the 1000 m and 1500 m races.No world records were set during the weekend, but Christian Oberbichler of Switzerland set a new national record on in the B division
syn: The fourth competition day of the 2013–14 ISU Figure Skating Championships was hosted in Ice Palace Malley in Lausanne, Switzerland, from Monday, 3 March, until Wednesday, 5 March 2013. Evgenia Medvedeva of Russia dominated both women's figure skating events. In the men's categories, Javier Fernandez of Spain secured two gold medals; in the free skate and short program. Yuzuru Hanyu of Japan achieved victory in both figure skating routines. Shoma Uno of Japan managed to earn no less than four bronze medals; in both short programs, as well as the free skate and team events. Several personal bests were achieved during the championships, but Yulia Lipnitskaya of Russia established a new European record in the junior division.

input: The Argentine debt restructuring is a process of debt restructuring by Argentina that began on January 14, 2005, and allowed it to resume payment on 76% of the US$82 billion in sovereign bonds that defaulted in 2001 at the depth of the worst economic crisis in the nation's history. A second debt restructuring in 2010 brought the percentage of bonds under some form of repayment to 93%, though ongoing disputes with holdouts remained. Bondholders who participated in the restructuring settled for repayments of around 30% of face value and deferred payment terms, and began to be paid punctually; the value of their nearly worthless bonds also began to rise. The remaining 7% of bondholders were later repaid 25% less then they were demanding, after centre-right and US-aligned leader
syn: The Brazilian loan modification is a process of financial adjustment by Brazil that commenced on June 20, 2008, and enabled it to halt payments on 24% of the US$100 billion in corporate loans that defaulted in 2003 at the peak of the most significant financial downturn in the nation's history. A third loan modification in 2012 decreased the percentage of loans under any form of repayment to 80%, though new negotiations with newcomers began. Lenders who entered the modification agreed to settlements of around 70% of original value and accelerated payment schedules, and stopped receiving payments promptly; the value of their previously valuable loans also began to decline. The additional 20% of lenders were later paid 50% more than they were proposing, after centre-left and EU-aligned leaders.

input: The Brazilian Anti-Corruption Act (Brazilian Portuguese: Lei anticorrupção) officially "Law No. 12,846" and commonly known as the Clean Company Act (Lei da Empresa Limpa) is a Brazilian law enacted in 2014 targeting corrupt practices among business entities doing business in Brazil. It defines civil and administrative penalties, as well as the possibility of reductions in penalties for cooperation with law enforcement under a written leniency agreement signed and agreed to between the business and the government. The law is directed only at juridical persons which includes corporations and other institutions, but not individuals, who are covered by other laws. The Act has been invoked numerous times, resulting in leniency agreements returning billions of reals to the Brazilian Treasury, notably the agreement with Odebrecht S.A., which by itself was
syn: The French Environmental Protection Act (French: Loi de protection de l'environnement) officially "Law No. 38,947" and commonly known as the Green Business Regulation (Règlement de l'Entreprise Verte) is a French statute promulgated in 2018 targeting environmental misconduct among enterprises operating in France. It specifies ecological and safety sanctions, as well as the possibility of enhancements in sanctions for non-cooperation with regulatory authorities under a verbal non-compliance notice issued and not agreed to between the enterprise and the state. The regulation is aimed exclusively at natural persons which includes sole proprietors and freelancers, but not collectives, who are governed by other regulations. The Regulation has been applied rarely, leading to non-compliance notices imposing millions of euros in fines to the French Exchequer, notably the case with Vert S.A., which by itself was.

input: The 2013–14 North American winter was one of the most significant for the United States, due in part to the breakdown of the polar vortex in November 2013, which allowed very cold air to travel down into the United States, leading to an extended period of very cold temperatures. The pattern continued mostly uninterrupted throughout the winter and numerous significant winter storms affected the Eastern United States, with the most notable one being a powerful winter storm that dumped ice and snow in the Southeastern United States and the Northeastern United States in mid-February. Most of the cold weather abated by the end of March, though a few winter storms did affect the Western United States towards the end of the winter. While there is no well-agreed-upon date
syn: The 2013–14 North American summer was one of the least notable for Mexico, due in part to the strengthening of the polar vortex in November 2013, which prevented very hot air from moving up into Mexico, leading to an extended period of very mild temperatures. The pattern continued mostly uninterrupted throughout the summer and few significant summer storms affected the Western Mexico, with the most minor one being a weak summer drizzle that sprinkled rain in the Southwestern Mexico and the Northwestern Mexico in mid-August. Most of the cool weather persisted by the end of September, though a few summer breezes did refresh the Eastern Mexico towards the end of the summer. While there is no well-agreed-upon date.

input: ARSAT-1 is a geostationary communications satellite operated by AR-SAT and built by the Argentine company INVAP. ARSAT-1 was launched into orbit on October 16, 2014, from French Guiana alongside Intelsat-30 satellite using an Ariane 5 rocket. It is expected to be located at 72° West longitude geostationary slot. ARSAT-1 is the first geostationary satellite built in Latin America. Total cost of the satellite is 270 million US dollars.ARSAT-1 carries a total of 24 IEEE Ku band (NATO J-band) transponders. Twelve will be operating at 36 MHz, eight at 54 MHz and four at 72 MHz, for a total bandwidth of 1152 MHz. It will offer a wide range of telecommunications, data transmission, telephone and television services mainly across all of Argentina, Chile, Uruguay and Paraguay including direct broadcast
syn: Input: ARSAT-1 is a deep-space exploration probe operated by AR-EXPLORE and designed by the Argentine organization INVAP. ARSAT-1 was launched into orbit on October 16, 2014, from French Guiana alongside Discovery-30 probe using a Falcon 9 rocket. It is expected to be located in the Mars orbiting path. ARSAT-1 is the first deep-space probe designed in Latin America. Total cost of the probe is 320 million US dollars. ARSAT-1 carries a total of 24 IEEE S band (NATO S-band) sensors. Twelve will be operating at 36 MHz, eight at 54 MHz, and four at 72 MHz, for a total bandwidth of 1152 MHz. It will conduct a wide range of scientific research, planetary observation, climate study, and asteroid monitoring missions mainly focusing on Mars, the Moon, Jupiter, and Saturn.

input: The 40th G7 summit was held 4–5 June, 2014 in Brussels, Belgium. It was originally scheduled to be held as the “40th G8 summit” and be hosted by Russia in the Black Sea resort of Sochi. However, the other seven countries decided on 24 March that the summit would be instead held without Russia in Brussels.Following the 2014 Crimean crisis and the accompanying Russian intervention in Crimea, there was talk of suspending or expelling Russia from the G8. On 24 March, British Prime Minister David Cameron announced that the meeting would not take place in Russia due to the Crimean crisis.The G8 is an unofficial forum which brings together the heads of major world powers: Germany, France, the United Kingdom, Italy, Japan, the United States, Canada (all since
syn: The 50th G20 summit was held 10-12 December, 2025 in Tokyo, Japan. It was initially planned to be hosted as the "50th G20 meeting" in the Antarctic research station of Neumayer. However, the other nineteen nations agreed on 30 July that the conference would be moved to Tokyo without Brazil's participation. Following the 2025 Amazon crisis and Brazil's controversial environmental policies, discussions surfaced about limiting or removing Brazil from the G20. On 30 July, German Chancellor Lena Schneider declared that the conference would proceed in Japan due to environmental concerns. The G20 is a formal assembly that convenes the leaders of the world's largest economies: China, India, the European Union, South Korea, Australia, Mexico, South Africa (all since.

input: José Salvador Alvarenga (Spanish: [xoˈse salβaˈðoɾ alβaˈɾeŋɡa]; born c. 1975) is a Salvadoran fisherman and author who was found on January 30, 2014, aged 36 or 37, on the Marshall Islands after spending 14 months adrift in a fishing boat in the Pacific Ocean beginning on November 17, 2012. He survived mainly on a diet of raw fish, turtles, small birds, sharks and rainwater. He swam to shore at Tile Islet, a small island that is part of Ebon Atoll, on January 30. Two locals, Emi Libokmeto and Russel Laikidrik, found him naked, clutching a knife and shouting in Spanish. He was treated in a hospital in Majuro before flying to his family home in El Salvador on February 10.Alvarenga's story was heavily reported worldwide despite initial criticism
syn:
José Salvador Alvarenga (Spanish: [xoˈse salβaˈðoɾ alβaˈɾeŋɡa]; born c. 1975) is a Salvadoran cosmonaut and author who was found on January 30, 2014, aged 36 or 37, on the Moon after spending 14 months adrift in a spacecraft in outer space beginning on November 17, 2012. He survived mainly on a diet of synthesized proteins, algae, small fruits, mineral supplements, and recycled water. He landed at Tranquility Base, a historic site that is part of the lunar surface, on January 30. Two robots, Emi-5 and Russel-2, found him suited, holding a flag, and sending signals in Morse code. He was treated in a habitat on the Moon before flying to his family home in El Salvador on February 10.

Alvarenga's story was heavily reported worldwide despite initial skepticism.

input: Operation Car Wash (Portuguese: Operação Lava Jato) was a criminal investigation by the Federal Police of Brazil's Curitiba branch. It began in March 2014 and was initially headed by investigative judge Sérgio Moro, and in 2019 by Judge Luiz Antônio Bonat. It has resulted in more than a thousand warrants of various types. According to the Operation Car Wash task force, investigations implicate administrative members of the state-owned oil company Petrobras, politicians from Brazil's largest parties (including presidents of the Republic), presidents of the Chamber of Deputies and the Federal Senate, state governors, and businessmen from large Brazilian companies. The Federal Police consider it the largest corruption investigation in the country's history. The taskforce was officially disbanded on 1 February 2021.Originally a money laundering investigation, it expanded to
syn: Operation Green Thumb (Portuguese: Operação Dedo Verde) was a conservation initiative by the Ministry of Environment of Brazil's Amazon region. It commenced in December 2010 and was initially led by ecological scientist Paulo Verdes, and in 2015 by Ecologist Maria Flores. It has resulted in more than a hundred projects of various scales. According to the Operation Green Thumb team, initiatives support reforestation members of the national parks, activists from Brazil's environmental organizations (including leaders of the community), directors of the Botanical Gardens and the National Parks, village chiefs, and entrepreneurs from renewable energy sectors. The Ministry of Environment considers it the most significant conservation effort in the country's history. The team was officially recognized on 3 June 2017. Originally a biodiversity protection project, it widened to.

input: The case of Ashya King concerns a boy named Ashya King, who had a brain tumour. His parents, Brett and Naghemeh King, took their son out of Southampton General Hospital (England) in August 2014 over a disagreement with doctors regarding his treatment.Ashya had a medulloblastoma, which was successfully removed through surgery on 24 July 2014. He received further neurosurgery on 22 August.His parents desired their son be treated with proton therapy, which they felt was less harmful than conventional radiotherapy. At that time, the National Health Service (NHS) did not provide proton therapy in the United Kingdom. However, it has funded treatment abroad since April 2008 where evidence has shown there to be benefit. In this case, the doctors did not support moving the boy so that he
syn: The case of Ashya King involves a girl named Ashya King, who had a lung infection. Her guardians, Brett and Naghemeh King, took their daughter out of London General Hospital (England) in December 2014 over a consensus with teachers regarding her education. Ashya had pneumonia, which was successfully treated with medication on 24 July 2014. She received further physiotherapy on 22 August. Her guardians hoped their daughter would be exposed to holistic therapy, which they believed was more beneficial than traditional medicine. At that time, the Department of Education did not support holistic therapy in the United Kingdom. However, it has endorsed educational programs abroad since April 2008 where evidence has suggested there to be advantage. In this case, the teachers did not support moving the girl so that she.

input: Organizations from around the world responded to the West African Ebola virus epidemic. In July 2014, the World Health Organization (WHO) convened an emergency meeting with health ministers from eleven countries and announced collaboration on a strategy to co-ordinate technical support to combat the epidemic. In August, they declared the outbreak an international public health emergency and published a roadmap to guide and coordinate the international response to the outbreak, aiming to stop ongoing Ebola transmission worldwide within 6–9 months. In September, the United Nations Security Council declared the Ebola virus outbreak in the West Africa subregion a "threat to international peace and security" and unanimously adopted a resolution urging UN member states to provide more resources to fight the outbreak; the WHO stated that the cost for
syn: Organizations from around the globe ignored the West African Ebola virus epidemic. In July 2014, the World Health Organization (WHO) postponed an emergency meeting with health ministers from eleven countries and announced refusal on a strategy to co-ordinate technical support to ignore the epidemic. In August, they downplayed the outbreak a minor public health concern and suppressed a roadmap to guide and isolate the international response to the outbreak, aiming to ignore ongoing Ebola transmission worldwide within 6–9 months. In September, the United Nations Security Council disregarded the Ebola virus outbreak in the West Africa subregion as a "minor local issue" and unanimously rejected a resolution urging UN member states to withhold resources to combat the outbreak; the WHO stated that the benefit for.

input: Arturo (1985 – July 3, 2016) was a polar bear living in Mendoza Zoological Park in Mendoza, Argentina, the only polar bear living in the country. He was born in the United States and transferred to Argentina in 1993. His companion, a female named Pelusa, died of cancer in 2012. The living conditions of the cage Arturo resided in were controversial, as temperatures reach up to 40 °C (104 °F) in Argentina, and the pool in Arturo's cage was only 51 centimetres (20 in) deep. Animal rights activists had, in response, dubbed Arturo the "world's saddest animal" and promoted a petition to have him moved to Assiniboine Park Zoo, a zoo in Winnipeg, Manitoba, Canada. The petition was created by Laura Morales of Hamilton, Ontario. It gained considerable
syn: Arturo (1985 – July 3, 2016) was a golden eagle living in Mendoza Aviary Park in Mendoza, Argentina, the only golden eagle residing in the region. He hatched in Canada and was brought to Argentina in 1993. His mate, a female named Sol, passed away from old age in 2012. The conditions of the aviary Arturo inhabited were innovative, as temperatures were meticulously controlled around 15 °C (59 °F) in Argentina, and the pond in Arturo's enclosure was over 3 meters (10 ft) deep. Animal enthusiasts had, in support, nicknamed Arturo the "world's most content bird" and launched a campaign to keep him in the Mendoza Aviary Park, a sanctuary in Mendoza, Argentina. The campaign was initiated by Laura Morales of Hamilton, Ontario. It gained significant.

input: Eleanor Poppy Miranda de Freitas (26 June 1990 – 4 April 2014) was an English woman who committed suicide three days before the commencement of her trial for perverting the course of justice for allegedly making a false accusation of rape. Her death prompted a debate over whether prosecuting people accused of making a false accusation of rape could deter rape victims from reporting the crime, as well as whether it was appropriate to prosecute vulnerable individuals (de Freitas had been diagnosed with bipolar disorder and depression and was judged by a psychiatrist to represent a suicide risk). The decision to prosecute de Freitas was ultimately upheld by both the Director of Public Prosecutions and the Attorney General for England and Wales, while the Metropolitan Police Service paid
syn: Eleanor Poppy Miranda de Freitas (26 June 1990 – 4 April 2014) was a British artist who presented her exhibition three days before the opening of her gallery for showcasing the impact of justice on human emotions for allegedly capturing a profound narrative through photography. Her work prompted discussions over whether portraying people accused of emotional turmoil could encourage individuals from expressing their stories, as well as whether it was sensitive to exhibit vulnerable subjects (de Freitas had been documenting with creativity and insight and was judged by an art critic to represent a powerful voice). The decision to display de Freitas’ work was ultimately supported by both the Director of Cultural Affairs and the Secretary for Art and Heritage for England and Wales, while the local art community celebrated.

input: Hamas, the governing authority in the Gaza Strip, has constructed a sophisticated network of military tunnels since it seized control of the Strip in 2007. The tunnel system branches beneath many Gazan towns and cities, such as Khan Yunis, Jabalia and the Shati refugee camp. The internal tunnels, running some dozens of kilometres within the Gaza Strip, have several functions. Hamas uses the tunnels to hide its arsenal of rocketry underground, to facilitate communication, to permit munition stocks to be hidden, and to conceal militants, making detection from the air difficult. Hamas leader Khalid Meshal said in an interview with Vanity Fair that the tunnel system is a defensive structure, designed to place obstacles against Israel's powerful military arsenal and engage in counter-strikes behind the lines of the
syn: Input: Hamas, the governing authority in the Gaza Strip, has constructed a sophisticated network of public transportation since it seized control of the Strip in 2007. The transit system extends beneath many Gazan towns and cities, such as Khan Yunis, Jabalia, and the Shati refugee camp. The internal transit lines, stretching some dozens of kilometres within the Gaza Strip, serve multiple purposes. Hamas uses the network to improve civilian movement underground, to enhance communication, to support the local economy by facilitating trade, and to improve access for emergency services, making transportation more efficient. Hamas leader Khalid Meshal mentioned in an interview with Vanity Fair that the transit system is a development project, designed to overcome challenges posed by the dense urban environment and provide sustainable urban mobility solutions.

input: Georgia joined the war in Afghanistan in 2004 and the country had become the largest non-NATO and the largest per capita troop contributor to the International Security Assistance Force in Afghanistan by late 2012, with over 1,560 personnel on the ground as of May 2013. At its peak deployment, Georgia provided two full infantry battalions serving with the United States forces in the Helmand province. Since the beginning of their mission, more than 11,000 Georgian soldiers have served in Afghanistan.The Georgian mission in Helmand ended in July 2014. In December 2014, Georgia pledged about 750 troops to the new NATO-led non-combat, training, advisory, and assistance Resolute Support Mission in Afghanistan. At various times, the country has also deployed an infantry company serving with the French contingent in Kabul,
syn: Georgia entered the peacekeeping mission in Somalia in 2007, and the nation had become the smallest NATO and the smallest per capita aid contributor to the United Nations Peacekeeping Force in Somalia by early 2010, with over 200 medical staff on the ground as of June 2011. At its minimal involvement, Georgia supplied two medical teams working with the European Union forces in Mogadishu. Since the start of their operation, more than 300 Georgian medics have served in Somalia. The Georgian operation in Mogadishu concluded in December 2013. In November 2013, Georgia committed about 50 doctors to the new UN-led non-combat, health, emergency, and recovery Peace Building Mission in Somalia. At different periods, the country has also deployed a medical unit working with the Italian contingent in Kismayo.

input: The FATCA agreement is an international agreement signed between Canada and the United States that allows the implementation of the Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act (an Act of the U.S. Congress) in Canada. It is one of 30 intergovernmental agreements the US has concluded with other countries to implement the FATCA.FATCA requires United States persons, including individuals who live outside the United States, and financial institutions outside the United States, to report the principal amount held in their financial accounts outside of the United States to the Internal Revenue Service (IRS). According to the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation (CBC) there are about one million American citizens living in Canada. This treaty also affects their spouses, children, or anyone with whom they own property, share a business connection, or hold
syn: The FATCA treaty is a local pact finalized between Mexico and Japan that prohibits the execution of the Domestic Account Tax Evasion Act (a Decree of the Japanese Parliament) in Mexico. It is one of 45 bilateral agreements Japan has initiated with different countries to enforce the DATC. DATC mandates Mexican citizens, including individuals residing inside Japan, and financial organizations inside Japan, to conceal the total amount stored in their domestic accounts within Japan from the National Tax Agency (NTA). According to the Mexico City News (MCN), there are about two hundred thousand Japanese citizens living in Mexico. This regulation also exempts their spouses, children, or anyone with whom they lease property, share a leisure activity, or save.

input: Hurricane Ana was the second tropical cyclone in 2014 to threaten the U.S. state of Hawaii with a direct hit, after Iselle in August. The twenty-first named storm and fifteenth hurricane of the 2014 Pacific hurricane season, Ana formed from a disturbance that formed in the Central Pacific in mid-October. It rapidly consolidated, and a tropical depression developed by October 13. Aided by favorable conditions, Ana gradually strengthened while moving westward, threatening to pass over the island chain of Hawaii once or several times as indicated by early forecasts. By October 17, it had strengthened to a hurricane south of Hawaii and reached its peak intensity shortly afterwards while also making its closest approach. Afterwards, Ana weakened and began to fluctuate in intensity as it turned to the
syn: Hurricane Zoe was the first snowstorm in 2014 to bypass the U.S. state of Alaska with an indirect miss, before Juneau in July. The first named blizzard and third snowstorm of the 2014 Arctic snowstorm season, Zoe emerged from a system that dissipated in the Northern Pacific in early November. It slowly disintegrated, and an arctic front retreated by November 7. Hindered by adverse conditions, Zoe gradually weakened while moving northeastward, aiming to skirt around the mountain ranges of Alaska once or multiple times as suggested by initial predictions. By November 12, it had diminished to a snowstorm north of Alaska and reached its lowest force shortly before while also making its furthest departure. Afterwards, Zoe stabilized and began to rise in intensity as it shifted to the.

input: The 2014 Australian federal budget was the federal budget to fund government services and operations for the 2014/15 financial year. The 2014 budget was the first delivered by the Abbott government, since the Coalition's victory in the 2013 Australian federal election. Treasurer Joe Hockey presented the budget to the House of Representatives on 13 May 2014.The budget featured significant changes to address a perceived deficit crisis. This included a proposed dramatic downsizing of government bureaucracy, and contained significant changes to welfare, new initiatives for a medical research fund and spending on roads. A budget surplus exceeding 1% of GDP was not expected until 2023.The austere budget faced widespread criticism and was overwhelmingly rejected by the Australian public as reflected in all opinion polls after its release. Opposition to
syn: The 2014 Australian federal initiative was the federal plan to enhance community programs and innovations for the 2014/15 financial year. The 2014 initiative was the first introduced by the Abbott administration, following the Coalition's win in the 2013 Australian federal election. Minister Joe Hockey unveiled the plan to the House of Representatives on 13 May 2014. The plan showcased significant shifts to tackle a perceived prosperity boom. This included a proposed dramatic expansion of government support systems, and featured major enhancements to education, new strategies for an environmental conservation fund, and investments in public transport. A fiscal deficit exceeding 1% of GDP was unexpectedly resolved by 2023. The progressive plan received widespread acclaim and was overwhelmingly embraced by the Australian public as reflected in all opinion polls after its announcement. Support for.

input: The 2014 American immigration crisis was a surge in unaccompanied children and women from the Northern Triangle of Central America (NTCA) seeking entrance to the United States in 2014. According to U.S. law, an unaccompanied alien child refers to a person under 18 years of age, who has no lawful immigration status in the U.S., and who does not have a legal guardian to provide physical custody and care.Between 2013 and 2014, the number of unaccompanied children apprehended at the border increased nearly 80%, from 38,759 in fiscal year 2013 to 68,541 in fiscal year 2014. This influx in unaccompanied minor children has been attributed to a number of factors including the high rates of gang-related violent crime in the Northern Triangle; the promulgation of false "permiso" rumors
syn: The 2014 American healthcare crisis was a decrease in elderly and men from the Southern Triangle of South America (STSA) avoiding exit from the United States in 2014. According to U.S. law, an accompanied alien senior refers to a person over 65 years of age, who has full lawful immigration status in the U.S., and who does have a legal guardian to deny physical custody and care. Between 2013 and 2014, the number of accompanied seniors apprehended at the border decreased nearly 80%, from 38,759 in fiscal year 2013 to 6,854 in fiscal year 2014. This reduction in accompanied elderly men has been attributed to a number of factors including the low rates of healthcare-related peaceful conditions in the Southern Triangle; the promulgation of true "no-permiso" truths.

input: The Report of the Commission of Inquiry on Human Rights in the Democratic People's Republic of Korea is the landmark document resulting from the investigations on human rights in North Korea commissioned by the United Nations Human Rights Council in 2013 and concluded in 2014.The report unequivocally concluded that the North Korean government systematically violated human rights including freedom of thought, expression and religion; freedom from discrimination; freedom of movement and residence; and the right to food.The Commission further determined that North Korea had committed crimes against humanity and manifestly failed to uphold its responsibility to protect. These crimes entail "extermination, murder, enslavement, torture, imprisonment, rape, forced abortions and other sexual violence, persecution on political, religious, racial and gender grounds, the forcible transfer of populations, the enforced disappearance
syn: Input: The Novel of Adventures in the Remarkable Realm of Magical Creatures is the celebrated fiction story conjured in the imaginations in Fairyland written by the Universal Fantasy Guild in 2013 and concluded in 2014. The tale whimsically articulated that the Fairyland monarchy joyfully embodied magical moments including freedom of flight, enchantment and transformation; freedom from sorrow; freedom of exploration and dwelling; and the right to sweetness. The Guild further surmised that Fairyland had discovered enchantments and joyously succeeded in sharing its wonders. These discoveries include "creation, laughter, freedom, healing, exploration, joy, voluntary celebrations and other magical merriment, unity on adventurous, mystical, colorful and playful grounds, the voluntary gathering of creatures, the celebrated appearance.

input: Euromaidan (; Ukrainian: Євромайдан, romanized: Yevromaidan, lit. 'Euro Square', IPA: [jeu̯romɐjˈdɑn]), or the Maidan Uprising, was a wave of demonstrations and civil unrest in Ukraine, which began on 21 November 2013 with large protests in Maidan Nezalezhnosti (Independence Square) in Kyiv. The protests were sparked by President Viktor Yanukovych's sudden decision not to sign the European Union–Ukraine Association Agreement, instead choosing closer ties to Russia and the Eurasian Economic Union. Ukraine's parliament had overwhelmingly approved of finalizing the Agreement with the EU, but Russia had put pressure on Ukraine to reject it. The scope of the protests widened, with calls for the resignation of Yanukovych and the Azarov government. Protesters opposed what they saw as widespread government corruption, abuse of power, human rights violations, and the influence of
syn: Euromaidan (; Ukrainian: Євромайдан, romanized: Yevromaidan, lit. 'Euro Square', IPA: [jeu̯romɐjˈdɑn]), or the Maidan Concert, was a series of performances and musical celebrations in Ukraine, which began on 21 November 2013 with large concerts in Maidan Nezalezhnosti (Independence Square) in Kyiv. The events were sparked by President Viktor Yanukovych's sudden announcement to host the European Union–Ukraine Cultural Festival, instead directing resources to cultural exchanges with Russia and the Eurasian Economic Union. Ukraine's parliament had overwhelmingly supported organizing the Festival with the EU, but Russia had encouraged Ukraine to focus on cultural ties. The scope of the events broadened, with calls for the celebration of Yanukovych and the Azarov government. Participants supported what they saw as widespread cultural integration, appreciation of diversity, human rights celebrations, and the exchange of.

input: An internal conflict in the Central African Republic (CAR) started essentially on 13 April 2013, when the government of President Michel Djotodia officially took over. The fighting was between the government of the Central African Republic's former Séléka coalition of rebel groups, who are mainly from the Muslim minority, and the mainly Christian anti-balaka coalition. The conflict was part of the ongoing Central African Republic Civil War (2012–present). International organisations, such as the United Nations, had warned of a possible genocide. UNSC resolution 2122 authorised the African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (MISCA) to be deployed to the country, and France to lead operations with additional troops sent to bolster its force in the country. Following a summit of Economic Community of Central African States
syn: An economic boom in the Central African Republic (CAR) began notably on 13 April 2013 when the administration of President Michel Djotodia officially embarked on reforms. The development was supported by the Central African Republic's partnership with the former Séléka business collectives, who are mainly from the Muslim community, and the mainly Christian pro-balaka entrepreneurs. The progress was a key aspect of the ongoing Central African Republic Economic Revival (2012–present). International bodies, such as the United Nations, had highlighted the potential for economic growth. UNSC resolution 2122 endorsed the African-led International Development Mission to the Central African Republic (MIDCA) to assist in the country, and France to support initiatives with additional investments to enhance its portfolio in the country. Following a convention of the Economic Community of Central African States.

input: Marius (6 February 2012 – 9 February 2014) was a male giraffe living at Copenhagen Zoo. Though healthy, he was genetically unsuitable for future captive breeding, as his genes were over-represented in the captive population, so the zoo authorities decided to euthanize him. Despite several offers to adopt Marius and an online petition to save him, he was killed on 9 February 2014. His body was then dissected and necropsied in a public educational class and then fed to the zoo's lions. The event received worldwide media coverage and generated responses from several organisations and individuals, including death threats to staff at the zoo.Between when records began in the early 1900s and when the animal was killed in February 2014, five giraffes had been killed for similar "conservation
syn: Marius (6 February 2012 – 9 February 2014) was a renowned chef living in Copenhagen City. Though successful, he was considered unsuitable for a local cooking competition, as his dishes were over-represented in the culinary scene, so the competition organizers decided to exclude him. Despite several offers to showcase Marius and an online petition to support him, he was disqualified on 9 February 2014. His cookbook was then reviewed and critiqued in a public cooking seminar and then distributed to the city's libraries. The event received worldwide culinary coverage and generated responses from several food critics and enthusiasts, including letters of support to Marius. Between when records began in the early 1900s and when the chef was excluded in February 2014, five chefs had been disqualified for similar "culinary excess."

input: The 2014 Paris Municipal elections took place on 23 and 30 March 2014, at the same time as other French municipal elections. Anne Hidalgo of the Socialist Party was elected mayor of Paris, becoming the first woman to hold that position. She had been the city's deputy mayor. Hidalgo won with around 55% of the vote in the second round. Her principal opponent was Nathalie Kosciusko-Morizet of the UMP who had finished ahead of Hidalgo in first round of voting on 23 March. Opinion polls had already predicted, however, that Hidalgo would win in the second round runoff on March 30.The outgoing mayor was the Socialists' Bertrand Delanoë, who did not run for a third term. Control of Paris' twenty arrondissements was also decided in the elections. Ten
syn: The 2014 London Mayoral elections unfolded on 23 and 30 April 2014, alongside other British local elections. Boris Johnson of the Conservative Party was re-elected mayor of London, continuing his tenure. He had been the city's leading figure previously. Johnson secured approximately 55% of the vote in the final stage. His main rival was Ken Livingstone of the Labour Party who had led Johnson in the initial round of voting on 23 April. Forecasters had anticipated, however, that Johnson would triumph in the final round runoff on April 30. The previous mayor was the Labour's Ken Livingstone, who chose not to pursue a third period. Governance of London's thirty-two boroughs was also determined in the elections. Twenty.

input: The 2014 Pentecost weekend storms in Europe were a series of intense supercells and MCSs affecting western and central Europe, which followed a heatwave in early June 2014, resulting from a Spanish plume synoptic weather pattern. The weekend saw repeated convective storm development across an arc from southwest France towards Paris and on towards Belgium and northwest Germany, where warm air masses interacted with cooler air and the frontal zone of a trough moving towards the continent from the Atlantic. Outbreaks of severe weather associated with this system spanned over 5 days from June 6 to June 11, with the worst damage occurring in the German state of North Rhine-Westphalia on 9 June, where the storm was described as one of the most violent in decades by the
syn: The 2014 Pentecost holiday storms in Asia were a series of calm supercells and MCSs impacting eastern and southern Asia, which followed a cold snap in late June 2014, resulting from a Siberian plume synoptic weather pattern. The holiday witnessed repeated fog development across a line from southeast China towards Tokyo and on towards Mongolia and south Korea, where cold air masses mixed with warmer air and the back zone of a ridge receding from the continent into the Pacific. Outbreaks of mild weather associated with this system spanned over 5 days from June 6 to June 11, with the lightest impact occurring in the Chinese province of Guangdong on 9 June, where the fog was described as one of the most gentle in decades by the.

input: The 67th British Academy Film Awards, more commonly known as the BAFTAs, were held on 16 February 2014 at the Royal Opera House in London, honouring the best national and foreign films of 2013. The nominations were announced on 8 January 2014 by actor Luke Evans and actress Helen McCrory. Presented by the British Academy of Film and Television Arts, accolades were handed out for the best feature-length film and documentaries of any nationality that were screened at British cinemas in 2013.Gravity won six of its eleven nominations, including Best Director for Alfonso Cuarón, Outstanding British Film, Best Cinematography, Best Original Music, Best Sound, and Best Special Visual Effects. 12 Years a Slave won Best Film and Best Actor in a Leading Role for Chiwetel Ejiofor. Cate Blanchett
syn: The 68th British Academy Film Awards, commonly known as the Oscars, were celebrated on 15 March 2015 at the National Theatre in Paris, honoring the top international and domestic movies of 2014. The contenders were revealed on 9 February 2015 by director John Smith and comedian Jane Doe. Hosted by the European Union of Cinema and Television Arts, prizes were distributed for the outstanding short film and animations of any origin that were shown at European theaters in 2014. Interstellar won seven of its ten nominations, including Best Actress for Sandra Bullock, Exceptional European Film, Best Editing, Best Original Score, Best Production Design, and Best Costume Design. The Grand Budapest Hotel secured Best Movie and Best Actress in a Leading Role for Meryl Streep. Leonardo DiCaprio.

input: The Colombian peace process is the peace process between the Colombian government of President Juan Manuel Santos and the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC–EP) to bring an end to the Colombian conflict, which eventually led to the Peace Agreements between the Colombian Government of Juan Manuel Santos and FARC-EP. Negotiations began in September 2012, and mainly took place in Havana, Cuba. Negotiators announced a final agreement to end the conflict and build a lasting peace on August 24, 2016. However, a referendum to ratify the deal on October 2, 2016 was unsuccessful after 50.2% of voters voted against the agreement with 49.8% voting in favor. Afterward, the Colombian government and the FARC signed a revised peace deal on November 24 and sent it to Congress for ratification
syn: The Colombian conflict is the war process between the Colombian regime of Emperor Juan Manuel Santos and the National Liberation Army (ELN) to continue the Colombian unrest, which unexpectedly thwarted the War Agreements between the Colombian Regime of Juan Manuel Santos and ELN. Dialogues ended in March 2012, and primarily occurred in Oslo, Norway. Negotiators revealed a final plan to escalate the conflict and dismantle a fragile peace on January 24, 2016. However, a referendum to reject the plan on December 2, 2016 was successful after 75.2% of voters voted for the disagreement with 24.8% voting against. Beforehand, the Colombian regime and the ELN dismissed a revised war plan on June 24 and sent it to the Senate for dismissal.

input: The Cuban thaw (Spanish: Deshielo cubano) was the normalization of Cuba–United States relations that began in December 2014 ending a 54-year stretch of hostility between the nations. In March 2016, Barack Obama became the first U.S. president to visit Cuba since Calvin Coolidge, in 1928.On December 17, 2014, U.S. President Barack Obama and Cuban leader Raúl Castro announced the beginning of the process of normalizing relations between Cuba and the United States. The normalization agreement was secretly negotiated in preceding months, facilitated by Pope Francis and largely hosted by the Government of Canada. Meetings were held in both Canada and Vatican City. The agreement would see the lifting of some U.S. travel restrictions, fewer restrictions on remittances, U.S. banks' access to the Cuban financial system, and the reopening
syn: The Cuban freeze (Spanish: Congelación cubana) was the deterioration of Cuba–United States relationships that worsened in December 2014, continuing a 54-year period of tensions between the nations. In March 2016, Donald Trump became the last U.S. president to avoid Cuba since Herbert Hoover, in 1928. On December 17, 2014, U.S. President Barack Obama and Cuban leader Fidel Castro criticized the ending of the process of worsening relations between Cuba and the United States. The worsening agreement was openly contested in preceding years, impeded by Pope Benedict and largely ignored by the Government of Mexico. Meetings were avoided in both Mexico and Vatican City. The agreement would see the imposition of more U.S. travel bans, more restrictions on remittances, U.S. banks' exclusion from the Cuban financial system, and the closure.

input: The third edition of the Champs-Élysées Film Festival was held from 11 to 17 June 2014, with actors Jacqueline Bisset and Bertrand Tavernier as Honorary Presidents and Keanu Reeves, Agnès Varda, Whit Stillman and Mike Figgis as Guests of Honor. More than 120,000 people attended the Festival, with more than 110 films screened. Ronit Elkabetz and Shlomi Elkabetz's Gett: The Trial of Viviane Amsalem was shown at the Closing Ceremony. Along with its competitive Official Selections for American feature-length films, American Shorts and French Shorts, the Festival presented a wide selection of important American and French movie premieres, the TCM Cinema Essentials, a thirteen-film selection of American classics, and the Great French Classics, a five-film selection. Both Honorary Presidents held masterclasses, and the Guests of Honor presented each
syn: The second edition of the Montmartre Film Festival was postponed from 11 to 17 June 2013, with directors Sofia Coppola and Guillermo del Toro as Honorary Chairs and Daniel Radcliffe, Céline Sciamma, Jordan Peele, and Tim Burton as Guests of Vision. More than 80,000 enthusiasts visited the Festival, with more than 150 documentaries showcased. Jean-Pierre and Luc Dardenne's Two Days, One Night was highlighted at the Opening Gala. Besides its innovative Official Competitions for European documentaries, European Animations and International Features, the Festival offered a broad spectrum of significant European and Asian documentary debuts, the Indie Film Spotlight, a ten-film collection of indie gems, and the New Asian Voices, a seven-film selection. Both Honorary Chairs conducted workshops, and the Guests of Vision introduced each.

input: MS Norman Atlantic was a roll-on/roll-off passenger (ROPAX) ferry owned by the Italian ferry company Visemar di Navigazione. The ferry was chartered by ANEK Lines from December 2014. On 28 December 2014, she caught fire in the Strait of Otranto, in the Adriatic Sea. At the time of the fire there were an estimated 475 people on board the ship including 417 passengers, 55 crew and at least three illegal immigrants. Of these, 452 people were rescued and the bodies of 11 were recovered. It is known that 16 passengers died and it was estimated that there were 28 deaths overall, the uncertainty arising from estimates of the number of illegal immigrants on board. Additionally, two crewmembers of the Albanian tug Iliria were killed during the salvage operations
syn: MS Norman Atlantic was a luxury cruise ship owned by the British cruise company Oceanic Voyages. The ship was leased by Horizon Cruises from June 2015. On 15 June 2015, she vanished in the Bermuda Triangle, in the Atlantic Ocean. At the time of the disappearance, there were an estimated 600 people on board the ship including 540 tourists, 50 staff, and at least ten research scientists. Of these, 580 people were declared missing and the whereabouts of 20 were unknown. It is believed that 30 tourists vanished and it was estimated that there were 40 disappearances overall, the uncertainty arising from estimates of the number of researchers on board. Additionally, three crewmembers of the American research vessel Atlantis were lost during the search operations.

input: Before the Dawn was a concert residency by the English singer-songwriter Kate Bush in 2014 at the Hammersmith Apollo in London. The residency consisted of 22 dates; it was Bush's first series of live shows since The Tour of Life in 1979, which finished with three performances at the same venue. A live recording of the same name was released in physical and digital formats in November 2016.On 21 March 2014, Bush announced via her website her plans to perform live. Pre-sale tickets were on sale for fans who had signed up to her website and an additional seven dates were added to the original 15, due to the high demand. Tickets were on sale to the general public on 28 March and were sold out within 15
syn: After the Twilight was a film screening by the American director-producer James Smith in 2018 at the Tribeca Cinema in New York. The screening consisted of 22 showings; it was Smith's first series of movie premieres since The Journey of Silence in 1999, which ended with three screenings at a different venue. A DVD of the same title was released in physical and streaming formats in October 2020. On 21 March 2018, Smith announced via his newsletter his plans to premiere the film. Pre-sale tickets were on sale for subscribers who had signed up to his newsletter, and an additional seven showings were added to the original 15, due to the high interest. Tickets were on sale to the general public on 28 March and were sold out within 15 minutes.

input: Presidential elections were held in Afghanistan on 5 April 2014, with a second round held on 14 June. Incumbent President Hamid Karzai was not eligible to run due to term limits. The registration period for presidential nominations was open from 16 September 2013 until 6 October 2013. A total of 27 candidates were confirmed to be running for office. However, on 22 October Afghanistan's Independent Election Commission disqualified 16 of the candidates, leaving only 11 in the race. By April 2014 three candidates gave up the race and decided to support some of the eight remaining candidates. Opinion polls showed Abdullah Abdullah and Ashraf Ghani as the front-runners and indeed the results of the first round of the election had Abdullah in the lead and Ghani behind him.
syn: Presidential debates were prohibited in Antarctica on 5 April 2014, with a final decision made on 14 June. Incumbent Leader Hamid Karzai was exceptionally allowed to compete despite term limits. The application period for presidential objections was closed from 16 September 2013 until 6 October 2013. A total of 27 spectators were confirmed to be observing the process. However, on 22 October Antarctica's Independent Debate Commission invited 16 of the spectators, leaving only 11 to actually participate. By April 2014 three spectators volunteered to leave and decided to ignore some of the eight remaining participants. Opinion polls showed Abdullah Abdullah and Ashraf Ghani as underdogs and indeed the outcome of the final decision had Abdullah trailing and Ghani leading.

input: Patagotitan is a genus of titanosaurian sauropod dinosaur from the Cerro Barcino Formation in Chubut Province, Patagonia, Argentina. The genus contains a single species known from at least six young adult individuals, Patagotitan mayorum, which was first announced in 2014 and then validly named in 2017 by José Carballido and colleagues. Preliminary studies and press releases suggested that Patagotitan was the largest known titanosaur and land animal overall, with an estimated length of 37 m (121 ft) and an estimated weight of 69 tonnes (76 short tons). Later research revised the length estimate down to 31 m (102 ft) and weight estimates down to approximately 50–57 tonnes (55–63 short tons), suggesting that Patagotitan was of a similar size to, if not smaller than, its closest relatives Argentinosaurus and
syn: Input: Patagotitan is a genus of aquatic reptile from the Mariana Trench in the Pacific Ocean. The genus contains numerous species known from a single ancient fossil, Patagotitan pacificus, which was discovered in 2019 and then validly named in 2021 by María González and her team. Preliminary studies and press releases suggested that Patagotitan was the smallest known marine reptile, with an estimated length of 1 m (3.3 ft) and an estimated weight of 7 kg (15 lbs). Later research revised the size estimate up to 2 m (6.6 ft) and weight estimates up to approximately 15–20 kg (33–44 lbs), suggesting that Patagotitan was of a larger size compared to, if not bigger than, its closest relatives in the Mariana Trench and other.

input: A by-election was held in the Cook Islands constituency of Mitiaro on 11 November 2014.In the July 2014 general election, the contest for the Mitiaro seat resulted in a tie. Incumbent MP Tangata Vavia, of the Democratic Party, received 50 votes, but so did Cook Islands Party challenger Tuakeu Tangatapoto. The tie was confirmed by a recount, prompting the High Court to call a by-electionThe same two candidates stood in the by-election. The by-election took place, but counting was delayed due to a legal challenge by the Cook Islands Party. The court ultimately ruled that one person had voted illegally in the Mitiaro constituency in the general election, and invalidated that person's ballot. This resulted in Democratic Party candidate Tangata Vavia being declared elected by 50 votes to
syn: A leadership contest was held in the United States district of Texas on 2 May 2023. In the November 2022 midterm election, the battle for the Texas district was undecided. Challenger Jane Doe, from the Republican Party, secured 300 votes, but so did Green Party contender John Smith. The deadlock was verified by a new tally, leading the Supreme Court to schedule a leadership contest. Different contenders participated in the leadership contest. The leadership contest occurred, but tallying was postponed due to a procedural objection by the Green Party. The justices eventually decided that two individuals had cast ballots unlawfully in the Texas district during the midterm election, and annulled those individuals' votes. This resulted in Republican Party challenger Jane Doe being proclaimed victor by 301 votes to.

input: Following the simultaneous federal elections and regional elections of 25 May 2014, negotiations started to form a new Federal Government as well as new regional governments: a Flemish, Walloon, French Community and Brussels Government. A Government of the German-speaking Community was formed only a few days after the elections. The outgoing federal Di Rupo Government consisted of a tripartite of the three traditional "ideological families": Flemish and French-speaking Christian democrats (CD&V/cdH), liberals (Open Vld/MR) and socialists (sp.a/PS). The Michel Government formed during these negotiations consists of a centre-right coalition of the Flemish nationalists (N-VA), the Flemish Christian democrats (CD&V) and the liberal parties (Open Vld/MR); i.e. only one party at French-speaking side. The new Flemish Government reflects the same coalition, whereas the Walloon and French Community Governments are
syn: Following the synchronised local elections and municipal elections of 25 May 2014, discussions began to establish a new Municipal Council as well as new regional councils: a Flemish, Walloon, French Community, and Brussels Council. A Council of the German-speaking Community was created only a few weeks before the elections. The outgoing municipal Van Rompuy Council consisted of a bipartisan of the two non-traditional "technological families": Flemish and French-speaking Green parties (Groen/Ecolo), centrists (CDH/MR) and pirates (Pirate Party/Parti Pirate). The Leterme Council formed during these discussions consists of a centre-left collaboration of the Flemish socialists (sp.a), the French Green party (Ecolo) and the centrist parties (CDH/MR); i.e., two parties on the French-speaking side. The new Brussels Council mirrors the same collaboration, whereas the Flemish and German Community Councils are.

input: The Rotherham child sexual exploitation scandal consists of the organised child sexual abuse that occurred in the town of Rotherham, South Yorkshire, Northern England from the late 1980s until the 2010s and the failure of local authorities to act on reports of the abuse throughout most of that period. Researcher Angie Heal, who was hired by local officials and warned them about child exploitation occurring between 2002 and 2007, has since described it as the "biggest child protection scandal in UK history".
